State Law reference- Aviation generally, MCA 1972, § 61-1-1 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 14-1-14-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - MUNICIPAL AIRPORT[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Municipal Airport Law, MCA 1972, § 61-5-1 et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 14-26. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Airport means the municipal airport located north of State Highway Number 8 and west of Ronaldman Road. 
    Airport manager means the officer or representative of the city having immediate charge of the airport. 
    FAA means the Federal Aviation Administration. 
    Fixed base operations means any person entering in to any of the activities coming under division 3 of this article. 
(Code 1996, § 14-26; Ord. of 11-4-1986, §§ 1, 8.14) 
Sec. 14-27. - General authority of manager. 
    The airport manager shall at all times have authority to take such action as may be necessary in the handling, conduct, and management of the public in attendance at the airport and enforce the provisions of this article. In any contingencies not specifically covered by the provisions of this article, the airport manager shall be authorized to make such rules and orders and render such decisions as to him may seem proper. 
(Code 1996, § 14-27; Ord. of 11-4-1986, § 2) 
Sec. 14-28. - Regulation of commercial enterprises. 
    The city has the right to regulate all commercial enterprises using the airport as a basis of operation, whether such operation is aeronautical or non-aeronautical in nature. No commercial operation of any kind or type shall be conducted on the airport unless specifically authorized by the city. 
(Code 1996, § 14-28; Ord. of 11-4-1986, § 3.1) 
Sec. 14-29. - Flying clubs. 
    A flying club is recognized as a plan for the joint ownership of aircraft and the fair distribution of the cost of maintaining and operating such aircraft. Such operation is not considered to be commercial in nature when so operated. Neither is flight instruction by club members for other club members considered to be commercial in nature so long as there is no profit or for-hire motives involved in the operation. In all cases the city will determine if the operation of a flying club or other such organization is commercial. If determined to be commercial, the club shall conform to the requirements set forth in division 3 of this article for commercial fixed base operators. 
(Code 1996, § 14-29; Ord. of 11-4-1986, § 3.2) 
Sec. 14-30. - Responsibilities of user of airport. 
(a)  The use of the airport or any of its facilities in any manner shall create an obligation on the part of the user thereof to obey all the regulations herein provided and adopted by the city. 
(b)  The privilege of using the airport and its facilities shall be conditioned on the assumption of full responsibility and risk by the user thereof, and he shall release and hold harmless and indemnify the city, its officers and employees from any liability of loss resulting from such use, as well as claims of third persons using the airport. 
(c)  The privilege of using the airport shall be upon the further condition that any person desiring to use the same shall furnish a policy of indemnity against personal injury and property damage in such sum as the city shall require. 
(Code 1996, § 14-30; Ord. of 11-4-1986, § 3.3) 
Sec. 14-31. - Violations of rules, regulations. 
    Any person violating any of the airport rules and regulations may be suspended from operations or presence at the airport by the city or airport manager, and such violation is and shall be a misdemeanor punishable as provided by law. 
(Code 1996, § 14-31; Ord. of 11-4-1986, § 3.4) 
Sec. 14-32. - Solicitation of funds. 
    No person shall solicit funds for any purpose and no signs, advertisements or circulars may be posted or distributed at the airport without permission of the city. 
(Code 1996, § 14-32; Ord. of 11-4-1986, § 3.5) 
Sec. 14-33. - Disposition of wastes. 
    Garbage, refuse and other waste material accumulated on airport property shall be placed in receptacles provided for such purpose. 
(Code 1996, § 14-33; Ord. of 11-4-1986, § 3.6) 
Sec. 14-34. - Malicious mischief. 
    No person shall destroy, remove or disturb in any way buildings, signs, equipment, markers or other property on the airport. 
(Code 1996, § 14-34; Ord. of 11-4-1986, § 3.6) 
Sec. 14-35. - Fire regulations. 
(a)  Smoking or lighting of an open flame is prohibited at places with posted signs, within 50 feet of any aircraft and within 50 feet of hangers, fuel trucks, or fuel stations and tank farms. 
(b)  No person shall start an open fire any place on the airport without permission of the airport manager. 
(c)  No person shall store material or equipment, use flammable or combustible liquids or gases or allow their premises to become in such condition so as to violate in any manner the fire code in force in the area of the airport. 
(d)  Tenants of all hangars and buildings shall provide suitable fire extinguishers and equipment and they shall be kept in good condition as recommended by the fire inspector and inspected at least every 12 months by trained personnel. 
(e)  Tenants and persons are required to keep their premises clean and clear of all rubbish, junk, debris, old aircraft and vehicles and any other unsightly objects. If, after warning by the airport manager, the area is not cleaned, cleaning will be done by the airport manager and billed to the tenant or person. 
(f)  Routine aircraft maintenance work may occasionally be done in a hangar used for the storage of aircraft, but no hazardous activities such as the transfer of fuel, welding, cutting, doping or spraying shall be permitted. Working on motor vehicles inside hangars is prohibited. 
(Code 1996, § 14-35; Ord. of 11-4-1986, § 7) 
Sec. 14-36. - Regulations and requirements for buildings and facilities. 
(a)  Hangars shall contain a minimum of 7,500 square feet of floor space in the hangar. Buildings shall be fireproofed and of metal or masonry construction, properly designed doors at both ends, stressed in accordance with the National Building Code, floor and ramps of concrete or properly compacted subgrade of sufficiently designed load strength to sustain all types of aircraft which it is planned to have use the facility. 
(b)  An area of 500 square feet of office space, restrooms and lounge which may be adjunct to other buildings, must also be fireproofed and of steel and masonry construction. 
(c)  Sufficient outside hose connections for washing of aircraft and other purposes, such as washing ramps, watering shrubbery, etc., must be installed. Should any new building be constructed over 1,000 feet from an existing fireplug, a new plug shall be provided. 
(d)  Paved areas for parking and access shall be provided, and such paving shall meet the standards for paving for this purpose. 
(Code 1996, § 14-36; Ord. of 11-4-1986, § 9) 
Sec. 14-37. - Motor vehicle regulations. 
(a)  Unless authorized by the airport manager, no highway or automotive vehicle shall be operated on the airport except on roadways, parking area, etc., that are specifically designated for such vehicles. Such vehicles shall be parked in the manner prescribed by the airport manager while on the airport and as indicated by posted signs. 
(b)  Fixed base operator customers shall park in areas designated by the airport manager. 
(c)  The area east of the main hangar is designated a temporary parking zone with a four-hour time limit. 
(d)  When aircraft are parked on the ramp or apron for the purpose of loading or unloading, no vehicle shall be driven between the aircraft and the loading gate or fence without permission of the airport manager. 
(e)  All vehicles operating within the landing area shall have prior permission of the airport manager. 
(f)  Every accident involving injury or property damage shall be reported to the airport manager. 
(g)  No person shall operate any vehicle in a careless or negligent manner or in disregard for the safety of others, or in excess of posted speed traffic signs. 
(h)  All persons are required to carry liability insurance on all vehicles. 
(Code 1996, § 14-38; Ord. of 11-4-1986, § 4) 
Secs. 14-38-14-55. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - AIRCRAFT OPERATIONS 

Sec. 14-56. - FAA rules, regulations. 
    The air traffic rules and aircraft operations regulations of the FAA are in effect and all additions thereto are made a part of this article as fully as if set forth herein. 
(Code 1996, § 14-56; Ord. of 11-4-1986, § 5.1) 
Sec. 14-57. - Running up of engines. 
    Aircraft engines shall be started and run up only in the places designated for such purposes. At no time shall engines be run up when hangars, shops, airplanes, or any buildings or persons are in the path of the propeller stream or jet exhaust. 
(Code 1996, § 14-57; Ord. of 11-4-1986, § 5.3) 
Sec. 14-58. - Parking-Generally. 
    No aircraft shall be parked, stored or repaired at the airport except in the areas designated for such use. 
(Code 1996, § 14-58; Ord. of 11-4-1986, § 5.4) 
Sec. 14-59. - Same-Prohibited areas. 
    Aircraft shall not be parked between the gasoline pumps and the flight operations area. 
(Code 1996, § 14-59; Ord. of 11-4-1986, § 5.2) 
Sec. 14-60. - Same-Moving to alternate location. 
    At the direction of the airport manager, the operator, owner or pilot of any aircraft on the airport shall move the aircraft from the place where it is parked or stored, to any other place designated on the airport. If the operator refuses to comply with the directions, the city, through the airport manager, may tow the aircraft to such place, at the operator's expense and without liability for damage that may result from such moving. 
(Code 1996, § 14-60; Ord. of 11-4-1986, § 5.5) 
Sec. 14-61. - Tie-downs. 
    Tie-down space is available to local aircraft owners. Each aircraft owner using a tie-down is responsible for furnishing his own tie-down ropes or chains, maintaining his area by keeping the grass mowed around the aircraft. 
(Code 1996, § 14-61; Ord. of 11-4-1986, § 5.6) 
Sec. 14-62. - Accident reports. 
    The pilot of an aircraft involved in an accident on or near the airport causing personal injury or property damage shall report to the airport manager. If he is unable to do so, the owner of the aircraft or his agent shall make such report. 
(Code 1996, § 14-62; Ord. of 11-4-1986, § 5.7) 
Sec. 14-63. - Damage to airport property. 
    Airport property damaged or destroyed by an accident or otherwise shall be paid for by parties responsible. 
(Code 1996, § 14-63; Ord. of 11-4-1986, § 5.8) 
Sec. 14-64. - Enforcement of charges. 
    The airport manager shall have the authority to detain any aircraft for nonpayment of any charges due. 
(Code 1996, § 14-64; Ord. of 11-4-1986, § 5.9) 
Sec. 14-65. - Taxiing. 
(a)  No person shall taxi an aircraft until he has ascertained by visual inspection of the area that there will be no danger of collision with any person or object in the immediate area. 
(b)  Aircraft shall be taxied at a safe and reasonable speed with due respect for other aircraft, persons or property. 
(Code 1996, § 14-65; Ord. of 11-4-1986, §§ 5.10, 5.11) 
Sec. 14-66. - Take-offs, landings. 
    All take-offs and landings shall be confined to the approved runway. 
(Code 1996, § 14-66; Ord. of 11-4-1986, § 5.12) 
Sec. 14-67. - Access to certain areas restricted. 
    No person, except airmen, duly authorized personnel, passengers going to or from the aircraft or persons being personally conducted by airport attendants, shall be permitted to enter the landing area proper, taxi space or aprons. However, this does not give any person so excepted the privilege or unrestricted use of the airport. These privileges are confined to the necessary use of these spaces in connection with the flights, inspections and routine duties. 
(Code 1996, § 14-67; Ord. of 11-4-1986, § 5.13) 
Sec. 14-68. - Rules for aircraft fueling operations. 
(a)  No aircraft shall be fueled or drained while the aircraft engine is running or while the aircraft is in a hangar or an enclosed area. 
(b)  During all fuel operations, the aircraft shall be grounded by an approved method. 
(c)  Smoking or lighting an open flame shall be prohibited within 50 feet of any fueling operation. 
(d)  Fueling operations shall be conducted and fuel trucks shall be parked at least 50 feet from any hangar or building. 
(e)  All fuel dispensing equipment shall be of a modern design and shall be kept in a safe and non-leaking condition. 
(Code 1996, § 14-68; Ord. of 11-4-1986, § 6) 
Secs. 14-69-14-85. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - FIXED BASE OPERATORS 

Sec. 14-86. - Conduct of business generally. 
    All fixed base operations at the airport shall be full-time, progressive business enterprises, with a manned office facility at the airport during all business hours. 
(Code 1996, § 14-86; Ord. of 11-4-1986, § 8.1) 
Sec. 14-87. - Performance bond. 
    Fixed base operators will be required to furnish the city a performance bond commensurate with construction required under the minimum standards of services to be performed. 
(Code 1996, § 14-87; Ord. of 11-4-1986, § 8.2) 
Sec. 14-88. - Construction standards. 
    All construction required of the operation of a business under this division shall be in accordance with design and construction standards established by the city for the facility involved. 
(Code 1996, § 14-88; Ord. of 11-4-1986, § 8.3) 
Sec. 14-89. - Conformance standards; lease required. 
    The city shall determine substantial conformance to the standards for fixed base operators. No fixed base operator shall be allowed to operate on the airport without a fully executed lease agreement with the city. 
(Code 1996, § 14-89; Ord. of 11-4-1986, § 8.4) 
Sec. 14-90. - Minimum liability insurance required. 
    Fixed base operators and other airport users shall carry liability insurance for bodily injury and property damage in such amounts as shall be fixed by order of the mayor and board of aldermen or the municipal airport commission. 
(Code 1996, § 14-90; Ord. of 11-4-1986, § 8.6) 
Sec. 14-91. - Sale of petroleum products, hangar rental. 
    Fixed base operators providing the sale of aviation petroleum products and hangar rental must meet the minimum standards as shown herein and provide all services and meet all the requirements listed below in sections 14-87 through 14-90. 
(Code 1996, § 14-91; Ord. of 11-4-1986, § 8.7) 
Sec. 14-92. - Ramp services. 
    Ramp services shall be provided full-time during daylight hours and by call at night, seven days a week, by the fixed base operator. 
(Code 1996, § 14-92; Ord. of 11-4-1986, § 8.9) 
Sec. 14-93. - Aircraft maintenance and repairs. 
    The fixed base operator shall lease from the city, or construct and maintain, a properly equipped hangar of at least 4,000 square feet and shall provide the services of at least one full-time certified A & P mechanic, and as many properly FAA certified personnel as may be required to perform all various aircraft maintenance and repairs in accordance with all rules and regulations and directions of the FAA and other governmental bodies having jurisdiction thereof. 
(Code 1996, § 14-93; Ord. of 11-4-1986, § 8.10) 
Sec. 14-94. - Aircraft sales. 
    The fixed base operator selling aircraft shall provide and maintain a minimum of 2,000 square feet of hangar, showroom and office space. This shall be a full-time progressive business operation providing sales facilities and sales personnel during normal daily business hours. 
(Code 1996, § 14-94; Ord. of 11-4-1986, § 8.11) 
Sec. 14-95. - Flight services. 
    The fixed base operator may engage in any one or all of the following services: flight instruction, charter service, or aircraft rental. The fixed base operator must provide and maintain a full-time office at the airport and provide full-time necessary office personnel. The fixed base operator must provide only properly certified instructors and pilots with ratings and qualifications as required by the FAA in the performance of all operations outlined in this division. 
(Code 1996, § 14-95; Ord. of 11-4-1986, § 8.12) 
Sec. 14-96. - Miscellaneous services. 
    Miscellaneous operations such as radio and instrument repairs, aerial advertising, crop dusting and other aeronautical activities not otherwise provided for in this division may be conducted by any person upon application to and approval of the city. Reasonable terms and conditions for the privilege of engaging in these various services will be established by the city commensurate with the nature and scope of the activities involved. 
(Code 1996, § 14-96; Ord. of 11-4-1986, § 8.13) 
Sec. 14-97. - Scope of operations. 
    Fixed base operators providing services in sections 14-90 and 14-91 or fixed base operations as defined in section 14-19 must meet the established standards for the given services but may not engage in sale of aviation petroleum products or hangar rental without complying with section 14-28. 
(Code 1996, § 14-97; Ord. of 11-4-1986, § 8.8)

Sec. 18-19. - Penalty. 
    Any responsible party who violates any of the provisions of this article or the codes listed herein shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor upon conviction, punishable by a fine of not less than $100.00 or more than $1,000.00, or by imprisonment of not less than 30 days or more than 90 days or by both such fine and imprisonment. Each day that a violation continues to exist after due notice is provided shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. of 2-13-2015(1), § 9) 
Sec. 18-20. - Official copies. 
    Three copies of the codes and standards adopted in this article shall be on file in the office of the building official and said documents shall be marked and designated as the official codes and standards for the city, 
(Ord. of 2-13-2015(1), § 1)

The adopted flood hazard map and supporting data are hereby adopted by reference and declared to be part of this section.

Exception: The location of the arc-fault circuit interrupter shall be permitted to be at other than the origination of the branch circuit, provided that: 
(i)  The arc-fault circuit interrupter is installed within six feet of the branch circuit overcurrent device as measured along the branch circuit conductors; and

Any person who shall continue any work on the system after having been serviced with a stop work order, except such work as that person is directed to perform to remove a violation or unsafe condition, shall be liable for a fine of not less than $100.00 or more than $1,000.00.

c.  Section 112.4-Failure to comply: Any person who shall continue any work after having been served with a stop work order, except such work as that person is directed to perform to remove a violation or unsafe condition, shall be liable to a fine of not less than $100.00 or more than $1,000.00. 
d.  Section 302.4-Weeds: Premises and exterior property shall be maintained free from weeds or plant growth in excess of 12 inches. Noxious weeds shall be prohibited. Weeds shall be defined as all grasses, annual plants and vegetation, other than trees or shrubs provided; however, this term shall not include cultivated flowers and gardens. Upon failure of the owner or agent having charge of a property to cut and destroy weeds after service of a notice of violation, they shall be subject to prosecution in accordance with section 106.3 and as prescribed by the authority having jurisdiction. Upon failure to comply with the notice of violation, any duly authorized employee of the jurisdiction or contractor hired by the jurisdiction shall be authorized to enter upon the property in violation and cut and destroy the weeds growing thereon, and the costs of such removal shall be paid by the owner or agent responsible for the property.

Section 304.14-Insect screens: Delete the language of this section in its entirety and replace with the following: "Every door, window and other outside opening required for ventilation of habitable rooms, food preparation areas, food service areas or any areas where products to be included or utilized in food for human consumption are processed, manufactured, packaged or stored shall be supplied with approved tightly fitting screens of minimum 16 mesh per inch (16 mesh per 25 mm), and every screen door used for insect control shall have a self-closing device in good working condition. Exception: Screens shall not be required where other approved means, such as air curtains or insect repellent fans, are employed." 
f.  Section 602.3-Heat supply: Delete the language of this section in its entirety and replace with the following: "Every owner and operator of any building who rents, leases or lets one or more dwelling units or sleeping units on terms, either expressed or implied, to furnish heat to the occupants thereof shall supply heat in order to maintain a minimum temperature of 68°F (20°C) in all habitable rooms, bathrooms and toilet rooms." 
g.  Section 602.4-Occupiable work spaces: Delete the language of this section in its entirety and replace with the following: "Indoor occupiable work spaces shall be supplied with heat to maintain a minimum temperature of 65°F (I8°C) during the period the spaces are occupied."

Sec. 18-22. - Fire district. 
(a)  There is hereby created and established a fire district within the city, which shall include all territory zoned as B-1, B-2, B-2H, M-1, and X-1 therein according to article VI of the Land Development Ordinance adopted by the mayor and board of aldermen on March 9, 2010, and any territory that is hereafter changed or zoned to be included within any of said districts. 
(b)  All buildings or structures within said zoning districts shall be built according to the requirements for fire districts as set forth in the codes and ordinances of the city, except that any building not classified as a hazardous use or a multiple occupancy use in said districts and being separated from any other building or occupancy by at least 25 feet need not comply with said fire district requirements but shall comply with the requirements of the applicable codes and ordinances for the proposed use. 
(Ord. of 8-6-2013, §§ 1, 2) 
State Law reference- Authority to establish fire limits, MCA 1972, § 21-19-21.
