ARTICLE III. - CONTRACTORS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Contractors, MCA 1972, § 31-3-1 et seq. 

Sec. 18-48. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Apprentice shall mean a full-time employee of a master or residential contractor as defined herein who performs electrical, gas pipe fitting, lawn irrigation, mechanical, or plumbing work under the direct supervision of a journeyman contractor, residential contractor, or master contractor. 
    Full-time employee shall mean a person who is an actual employee of the business, not an independent contractor. The person must work, on average, 30 or more hours a week for the business (1500 hours per year), must not be paid as an independent contractor (not receive a "1099" for his earnings but receive a "W-2" for his earnings). A full-time employee is not someone who is hired "job to job" as needed. Other factors to be considered in making this determination include, but are not limited to: whether the business pays for worker's compensation insurance on the individual, whether the business pays payroll taxes on the individual, the amount of control the business has over the activities of the individual, the ownership of the tools used by the individual and, whether the individual maintains his own business separate from the business in question. 
    Homeowner shall mean the person who lives in a single-family residence or is constructing a single-family residence for the purpose of living in themselves. 
    Journeyman contractor shall mean an experienced, reliable workman and licensed as such in the electrical, gas pipe fitting, mechanical, or plumbing trades who meets the qualifications set forth in this chapter. Journeyman contractors are only allowed to work directly under the supervision of a master or residential contractor. 
    Master contractor shall mean any qualifying person engaged in the business of installing, maintaining, altering, or repairing, electrical, gas pipe fitting, lawn irrigation, mechanical, or plumbing systems in, on, or under all types of buildings or structures and outside installations and licensed as such. A master contractor is allowed to work on any type of structure or project in the field(s) in which they hold a valid license. 
    Qualifying person shall mean the individual who has passed the appropriate examination from any source recognized herein. The license holder of a master or residential license must also be either: 
(1)  A sole owner; 
(2)  A partner of the partnership; 
(3)  An officer of the corporation who is actively engaged in the day to day activities of the company; 
(4)  A member of the limited liability company who is actively engaged in the day to day activities of the company; 
(5)  A partner of the limited liability partnership who is actively engaged in the day to day activities of the company; or 
(6)  A full-time employee. 
    Residential contractor shall mean any qualifying person engaged in or about to engage in the business of installing, maintaining, altering, or repairing electric or plumbing materials, fixtures, and equipment in, on, or under residential buildings including the premises adjacent to such buildings. Residential contractors are still categorized as master contractors except they are only allowed to only work on residential projects. 
(Ord. of 6-2-2015, § 1; Ord. of 12-1-2015(1), § 1; Ord. of 12-05-2017(1), § 1 ) 
Sec. 18-49. - General regulations. 
(a)  License required. When a permit is required to perform electrical, gas pipe fitting, lawn irrigation, mechanical, or plumbing work, any person doing such work other than as stated in subsection (b) herein shall either obtain a license from the City of Cleveland as stated in section 18-50 herein for such work or shall submit proof of a valid Mississippi State Board of Contractors license in that particular field along with all other required documentation prior to beginning any such work as stated in section 18-51 herein. 
(b)  Homeowner exemption. Any capable person who wishes to perform electrical, gas pipe fitting, lawn irrigation, mechanical, or plumbing work in or on a single-family residence in which they currently live or are constructing to live in themselves, or in or on any accessory structure associated with the single-family residence in which they live is hereby exempt from the regulations contained in this article unless otherwise specifically stated. Such homeowner shall be required to complete an owner/builder certification form stating that they will be performing the work themselves and not hiring anyone else to perform said work. It shall be unlawful and a violation of this article for any homeowner to obtain a permit through false pretenses or to hire an unlicensed person to perform work that would otherwise require a licensed contractor to perform while the owner is acting under the provisions of this exemption. Nothing in this section shall preclude the necessity of the homeowner from obtaining the required permits and inspections and from performing the work in accordance with all applicable codes. 
(c)  Supervision of work. Except for the homeowner exemption as stated herein, all electrical, gas pipe fitting, lawn irrigation, mechanical, and plumbing work shall be done under the direct supervision of a master or residential contractor. 
(Ord. of 6-2-2015, § 2; Ord. of 12-1-2015(1), § 2; Ord. of 12-05-2017(1), § 2 ) 
Sec. 18-50. - Contractor licenses. 
(a)  Classification of licenses. For the purposes of receiving a license under the provisions of this article, licenses issued by the City of Cleveland shall be classified as follows: 
(1)  Master electrical. 
(2)  Residential electrical. 
(3)  Journeyman electrical. 
(4)  Master gas pipe fitter. 
(5)  Journeyman gas pipe fitter. 
(6)  Master lawn irrigation systems. 
(7)  Master mechanical. 
(8)  Journeyman mechanical. 
(9)  Master plumbing. 
(10)  Residential plumbing. 
(11)  Journeyman plumbing. 
(b)  Minimum qualifications for licenses granted by the city. Licenses issued by the City of Cleveland are specific to an individual qualifying person and not issued to a business, and as such said license(s) automatically expire upon death or retirement of the license holder without any grace period. A separate and distinct privilege license is required in order for a business to operate. An applicant for any classification of license must be at least 21 years of age and meet other minimum qualifications for each classification as stated herein. 
(1)  Master contractor. In addition to passing the appropriate examination(s), an applicant for a master contractor license shall have had at least three years of training as an apprentice or the equivalent in a recognized technical school or college, and in addition thereto, shall have had at least two years of experience as a journeyman, or in lieu thereof, shall have had at least six years of training as an apprentice during which at least three of those years must have been in commercial or industrial projects. 
(2)  Residential contractor. In addition to passing the appropriate examination(s), an applicant for a residential contractor license shall have had at least three years of training as an apprentice or the equivalent in a recognized technical school or college, and in addition thereto, shall have had at least two years of experience as a journeyman, or in lieu thereof, shall have had at least six years of training as an apprentice during which at least three of those years must have been primarily on residential projects. 
(3)  Journeyman contractor. In addition to passing the appropriate examination(s), an applicant for a journeyman contractor license shall have worked a minimum of three years under the supervision of a master or residential contractor as an apprentice, or the equivalent in a recognized technical school or college. 
(c)  Application required. Any qualifying person desiring to obtain a City of Cleveland contractor license shall file an application in person for such license(s) with the City of Cleveland at the department of community development. The application shall set forth the applicant's business address, phone number, training, and qualifications. In addition to the required license application, an applicant for a City of Cleveland contractor license shall also submit the following: 
(1)  A copy of a valid photo ID. 
(2)  A certificate of liability insurance $100,000.00/$300,000.00 with products completed coverage. The insurance certificate shall also show a valid expiration date and policy number. 
(3)  A bond in the amount of $5,000.00 issued to the City of Cleveland, Mississippi. The bond shall also show a valid expiration date. 
(4)  Master contractor applicants or residential contractor applicants employing five (5) or more full-time employees shall provide a certificate of worker's compensation insurance showing coverage for each of the full-time employees/apprentices listed on the application. 
(5)  Completed certification of employee/apprentice forms and copies of a W-4 or W-2 for each full-time apprentice listed on the application. 
(6)  Three letters of recommendation from persons with knowledge of work relating to the license(s) being applied for. 
(d)  Examination required. All applicants for any City of Cleveland contractor license(s) shall submit written proof of passing examination from the International Code Congress (ICC), the Mississippi State Board of Contractors (MSBOC), any source approved by the Contractor Licensing Board, or from another municipality or county within the State of Mississippi or other jurisdiction of reciprocity which has an examining board where there is regularly given a written examination. The passing examination provided shall be taken in the same field(s) of work as the license(s) being applied for and shall be sufficient to test the theoretical and practical knowledge of the applicant. All contractors currently licensed by the City of Cleveland, and in good standing on the effective date of this article shall be exempt from the aforesaid examination process. 
(e)  New license fee. The fee for each new contractor license shall be $75.00 each and licenses are valid for the calendar year or part thereof in which they are issued. 
(f)  License renewals. All contractor licenses issued by the City of Cleveland shall be renewed on or before December 31st of each year. The fee for each license renewal shall be $25.00 each if renewed by the required deadline. Contractor licenses not renewed by the deadline shall be subject to the following penalties: 
(1)  Contractors who are in good standing with the contractor licensing board but have failed to renew license(s) by the required December 31st deadline may renew said license(s) on or before a January 10th grace period by submitting a $250.00 late fee in addition to the required $25.00 renewal fee for each license. 
(2)  Contractors failing to renew license(s) by the January 10th grace period shall be subject to the license(s) being suspended until reinstated by the contractor licensing board at their next meeting. A $250.00 late fee and a $25.00 renewal fee for each license shall be submitted to the department of community development prior to license(s) reinstatement. 
(3)  Contractors failing to renew license(s) or submit application for reinstatement on or before January 31st shall be subject to all license(s) being revoked. 
(g)  Revocation. It shall be the duty of the contractor licensing board upon recommendation of the building official or building inspector and after sufficient hearing, to suspend or revoke or cause to be suspended or revoked, licenses and permits of any license holder for any of the following reasons: 
(1)  Willful misstatements or false statements in the license application; or 
(2)  Permitting the use of a license by any person other than the license holder; or 
(3)  Persistent refusal or neglect to observe the provisions of the applicable codes and ordinances; or 
(4)  Failure to renew license(s) or submit application for reinstatement on or before January 31st; or 
(5)  Any other act intended to violate the provisions of applicable codes and ordinances. 
The suspension or revocation of a license shall not serve as a bar to any further remedy or action at law which might be invoked by the City of Cleveland. 
(h)  Identification cards. It shall be unlawful for any duly licensed City of Cleveland master contractor, residential contractor, journeyman contractor, or any apprentice to work within the City of Cleveland without having in his/her possession, a valid identification card issued by the City of Cleveland designating the classification of license obtained for master, residential, or journeyman, or the classification as apprentice and the expiration date of such card. 
(i)  Identification on vehicles. Licensed master or residential contractors conducting business within the City of Cleveland shall have affixed or printed on any vehicle being used on a job site, a sign or lettering stating the name of the company and license number of the master or residential contractor. Such signage or lettering shall be in colors so as to be visible and easily readable. Failure to comply with this section shall result in the withholding of permits until such time as the license holder meets the requirements of this section. 
(Ord. of 6-2-2015, § 3(1)-(9); Ord. of 12-1-2015(1), § 3; Ord. of 12-05-2017(1), § 3 ) 
Sec. 18-51. - Reciprocal contractors. 
(a)  Classification of reciprocity. The City of Cleveland will recognize valid and current licenses issued by the Mississippi State Board of Contractors, and valid and current licenses issued by jurisdictions of reciprocity as defined by state statute without the contractor being required to obtain a City of Cleveland license provided that the reciprocal license is the same classification as licenses issued by the City of Cleveland and that the reciprocal contractor comply with the other requirements of this section. 
(b)  Application required. Any qualifying person requesting reciprocal contractor recognition shall file an application in person for reciprocity with the City of Cleveland at the department of community development. The application shall set forth the applicant's business address, phone number, and other information as required. In addition to the required license application, an applicant for reciprocity shall also submit the following: 
(1)  A copy of a valid photo ID. 
(2)  A certificate of liability insurance $100,000.00/$300,000.00 with products completed coverage. The insurance certificate shall also show a valid expiration date and policy number. 
(3)  A bond in the amount of $5,000.00 issued to the City of Cleveland, Mississippi. The bond shall also show a valid expiration date. 
(4)  Reciprocal contractor applicants employing five or more full-time employees shall provide a certificate of worker's compensation insurance showing coverage for each of the full-time employees/apprentices listed on the application. 
(5)  Completed certification of employee/apprentice forms and copies of W-4 or W-2 for each full-time apprentice listed on the application. 
(c)  Reciprocity fee. The fee for each reciprocity application shall be $75.00 each and reciprocity applications are only valid for the calendar year or part thereof in which they are issued. Reciprocal contractors must file a new application with supporting documentation and fee(s) each calendar year in which reciprocity is requested. 
(d)  Revocation. It shall be the duty of the contractor licensing board upon recommendation of the building official or building inspector and after sufficient hearing, to suspend or revoke the reciprocity and permits of any reciprocal contractor for any of the following reasons: 
(1)  Willful misstatements or false statements in the license application; or 
(2)  Permitting the use of a reciprocal license by any person other than the license holder; or 
(3)  Persistent refusal or neglect to observe the provisions of the applicable codes and ordinances. 
The suspension or revocation of a reciprocal application shall not serve as a bar to any further remedy or action at law which might be invoked by the City of Cleveland. In cases of misconduct of a reciprocal contractor, the City of Cleveland reserves the right to file a complaint with the jurisdiction or state issuing the original license. 
(e)  Identification on persons. Reciprocal contractors and their employees/apprentices conducting business within the City of Cleveland shall carry on their person a form of photo identification at all times and shall make the same available to the department of community development staff whenever required to ensure conformance with the provisions of this article. 
(f)  Identification on vehicles. Reciprocal contractors conducting business within the City of Cleveland shall have affixed or printed on any vehicle being used on a job site, a sign or lettering stating the name of the company and original license number of the master or residential contractor. Such signage or lettering shall be in colors so as to be visible and easily readable. Failure to comply with this section shall result in the withholding of permits until such time as the reciprocal contractor meets the requirements of this section. 
(Ord. of 6-2-2015, § 3(10); Ord. of 12-1-2015(1), § 4; Ord. of 12-05-2017(1), § 4 ) 
Sec. 18-52. - Contractor licensing board. 
(a)  Licensing board established. There is hereby established the contractor licensing board, herein referred to as the board. The board shall consist of nine members appointed by the mayor and board of aldermen upon recommendation of the building official. Each member's place of business must be based within the city limits of Cleveland or they must live within the city limits of Cleveland. The board shall be made up of seven city of Cleveland valid contractor license holders in any discipline, along with one residential builder and one commercial builder licensed by the Mississippi State Board of Contractors. The building official, assistant building official, building inspector, code enforcement officer, and city attorney shall serve as ex-officio, non-voting members of the board by virtue of their offices. 
(b)  Terms of office. The members of the contractor licensing board shall serve at the will and pleasure of the mayor and board of aldermen for the City of Cleveland, Mississippi. The terms of office for licensing board members shall be as follows: 
Three members shall serve until December 31, 2015. 
Three members shall serve until December 31, 2016. 
Three members shall serve until December 31, 2017. 
Following the first expiration of term, board positions will be filled to serve for a period of three years. All members shall be eligible for reappointment. 
(c)  Officers. The contractor licensing board shall elect one of its own members as chairman who shall preside at all meetings, and a vice-chairman who shall preside in the absence of the chairman. The chairman and vice-chairman positions shall be elected annually. The position of secretary shall be filled by a member of the department of community development staff. 
(d)  Duties. The contractor licensing board shall approve credentials, grant or deny applications for City of Cleveland licenses, receive complaints, conduct disciplinary hearings, suspend licenses, revoke licenses, make investigations, and recommend to the mayor and board of aldermen from time to time amendments and changes to the contractor licensing ordinance. The board reserves the right to deny issuance of a license to any person who the board determines to be unqualified or who has a record of performing unacceptable work which does not comply with the adopted codes of the City of Cleveland, Mississippi. Such determination shall be made at a board meeting where the applicant shall be given the right to answer all charges. Denial of a license shall require a 75 percent vote of the members in attendance. 
(e)  Meetings; quorum; records. Meetings of the contractor licensing board may be called at any time by the chairman, vice-chairman, building official, building inspector, or by a majority of the board provided that the board shall meet and act upon any application within 30 days after receipt of such application. A quorum of the board shall consist of five members, plus the building official or his representative. It shall be required of the board to open its meetings to the public as required by law. Minutes of each meeting shall be available and kept at the department of community development. 
(f)  Conflict of interest; vacancies; absences. No board member shall act in a case in which he/she has a personal interest. Vacancies on the board shall be filled in the same manner in which original appointments are required to be made. Board members that are absent from three consecutive meetings shall be dismissed from service unless a reasonable and valid excuse is given for the absences. 
(g)  Compensation. The members of the contractor licensing board shall not receive compensation for their service on the board. 
(h)  Appeal. Any party aggrieved by a decision of the contractor licensing board may appeal such decision in writing to the mayor and board of aldermen provided such appeal is made within 30 days following such decision. 
(Ord. of 6-2-2015, § 4; Ord. of 12-1-2015(1), § 5; Ord. of 12-05-2017(1), § 5 ) 
Sec. 18-53. - Penalties and violations. 
(a)  Any contractor licensed by the City of Cleveland to perform work as regulated by this article who violates any provisions of the codes and ordinances of the City of Cleveland pertaining to construction or contractor licensing and is found guilty of the same by the contractor licensing board shall be penalized after a hearing on such violation as follows: 
(1)  First offense: The contractor's license(s) shall be suspended for a period of 30days and a penalty in the amount of $250.00 shall be imposed. 
(2)  Second offense: The contractor's license(s) shall be suspended for a period of 90 days and a penalty in the amount of $500.00 shall be imposed. 
(3)  Third offense: The contractor's license(s) shall be suspended for a period of 180 days and a penalty of $1,000.00 shall be imposed. 
(b)  In addition to aforesaid prescribed penalties, any licensed contractor, homeowner, or reciprocal contractor who violates any provision of this article may be issued a citation to appear before the Municipal Court of the City of Cleveland, Mississippi, and upon conviction shall be found guilty of a misdemeanor offense and fined not less than $100.00 nor more than $1,000.00, or by imprisonment in the county jail not to exceed 90 days, or by both such fine and imprisonment. Each day that said violation continues to exist shall constitute a distinct and separate offense. 
(c)  Any licensed contractor, homeowner, or reciprocal contractor that fails to request a required inspection of the work being performed or who fails to request a final inspection within 30 days after completion of the project shall be subject to a penalty of $100.00 for each missed inspection. Failure to pay an inspection penalty will result in the inability to obtain further permits until said penalty has been paid in full. 
(d)  If a contractor's license is suspended, he/she shall be allowed to complete any jobs for which he/she hold an existing permit, however no further permits will be issued to the contractor during the period of suspension. The suspension period shall not commence until the final action is rendered by the contractor licensing board. 
(e)  If a violation of the construction codes of the City of Cleveland is not corrected within ten calendar days following notification to the permit holder by the city of the violation, no additional permits shall be issued to the offender until the violation(s) are corrected. Adequate notice shall be considered delivery of a letter through U.S. Postal Service to the address shown on the contractor's license application. The building official may grant an extension in time to correct the violation(s) if it is deemed appropriate for the amount of time necessary to physically correct the violation(s). 
(e)  The contractor licensing board on behalf of the City of Cleveland in its discretion may call, collect or otherwise demand the proceeds of the license bond from the bonding company of any license holder or reciprocal contractor who refuses or otherwise does not correct any violation of this article or the city's construction codes after having been given adequate time to correct the violation(s). The license shall automatically be revoked upon the calling of the bond. A locally licensed contractor shall not be granted another license in the City of Cleveland until after one year from the date of violation, and the license shall not be granted until the contractor satisfies any requirements outlined by the contractor licensing board. A reciprocal contractor shall not be allowed to obtain additional permits until after one year from the date of violation. 
(f)  The contractor licensing board shall also have the authority to suspend or revoke City of Cleveland licenses upon repeated violations. The license shall not be revoked until after the alleged offender has been given the opportunity to defend his/her actions in the form of a hearing with said licensing board. The City of Cleveland may also take any other legal action prescribed by law to uphold the provisions of this article in addition to the penalties prescribed herein. 
(Ord. of 6-2-2015, § 5; Ord. of 12-1-2015(1), § 6; Ord. of 12-05-2017(1), § 6 ) 
Secs. 18-54-18-77. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - NUMBERING BUILDINGS AND STRUCTURES 

Sec. 18-78. - Numbering required; application. 
(a)  All persons constructing new structures or locating or relocating mobile homes in the city shall apply for and obtain a designation of an address and serial number for such structure, and the form therefor shall contain information, and be substantially, as follows, and including any other information from the applicant and the city issuing authority as may be required in the administration of this article: 
ADDRESS AND SERIAL NUMBER DESIGNATION 
Date and time received:  _____ Name of resident or occupant:  _____ Old address (Not applicable _____):  _____  
Telephone number: 601 - _____  
Location of new address (described as):  _____ Signature of applicant:  _____  
Address number assigned: _____ Serial number assigned: _____ New address:  _____ Assigned by: _______ Date assigned: _______  
Occupancy inspection: Residential _____ Commercial _____ Temporary _____ Final _____ Notified: Phone company _____ Post office _____ Resident _____ Tax office _____ Electric power company _____ Gas company _____ Water department _____ 911 _____ Cable company _____ Solid waste disposal company _____  
(b)  An applicant shall file the application for address and serial number designation and occupancy certificate or permit with and to the city at the city hall or the department of public works. The applicant shall receive from the city sufficient copies of the designation and permit to present to the utility companies and the post office. 
(Code 1996, § 18-31; Ord. of 3-7-1995, § 1(a), (c)) 
Sec. 18-79. - Duties of the city. 
(a)  Upon proper filing of the application under this article with the building inspector or public works department, the inspector or the director of public works shall: 
(1)  Cause the code compliance staff to perform an occupancy inspection (residential or commercial) at the structure to determine compliance with minimum housing, zoning, other standards as already in force under the separate ordinances of this city; 
(2)  Inspect and determine, through the issuing authority, the proper address for the structure and that such number is displayed as required by this article, and follow with issuance of an occupancy permit, or at least, a temporary occupancy permit, as provided by current procedures; and 
(3)  Assign a number and address to the structure within two business days. 
(b)  Any address request presented after 3:00 p.m. will not be considered to have been presented until the next business day. 
(c)  The issuing office shall keep a record of all numbers and addresses assigned. 
(Code 1996, § 18-32; Ord. of 3-7-1995, § 1(d)) 
Sec. 18-80. - Posting of designated building numbers. 
    The owner or occupant or person in charge of any house, building, structure, mobile home or other structure to which a number has been assigned shall: 
(1)  Within 30 days after the receipt of a number issued under this article, affix the number in a conspicuous manner in a conspicuous place. 
(2)  Remove any different number which might be mistaken for or confused with the number assigned to such structure by the issuing authority. 
(3)  Maintain such number so that it will remain visible. 
(Code 1996, § 18-33; Ord. of 3-7-1995, § 2) 
Sec. 18-81. - Prerequisites for utility service. 
    No utility or public service company operating in the city shall furnish its utility or other services to any structure or mobile home, including a mobile home that is moved from one location to another, until it has been furnished with the house number, street name and serial number duly issued by the city for each new or successive occupant, and until it has been furnished with an occupancy permit or certificate, either temporary or permanent, from the city. 
(Code 1996, § 18-34; Ord. of 3-7-1995, § 1(b)) 
Sec. 18-82. - Coordination with emergency response system. 
    The numbers assigned in compliance with this article shall be communicated to any utility or other public service so requesting and to the county enhanced 911 emergency response system for structures within the city and such system, and such numbers, shall be controlled by the ordinances and regulations of the city. Obtaining and maintaining such number is for the convenience and safety of the owners of such structures. The failure to provide any such number, or the failure of any assigned number to be communicated to such emergency or other service or to remain or be visible as required by this article, shall not impose any liability for damages or for inconvenience or for any other obligation upon this city or any inspector or official connected therewith. 
(Code 1996, § 18-35; Ord. of 3-7-1995, § 4) 
Secs. 18-83-18-107. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - RENTAL REGISTRATION[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. of 02-07-2017(2) , adopted February 7, 2017, repealed the former Art. V., §§ 18-108-18-116, and enacted a new Art. V. as set out herein. The former Art. V. pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Ord. of February 21, 2006, §§ I-IX. 

Sec. 18-108. - Title. 
    This article shall be known and cited as the "Rental Registration Ordinance." 
( Ord. of 02-07-2017(2) ) 
Sec. 18-109. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this article is to provide for the routine inspection of residential rental dwellings or units within the city to ensure that all residential rental structures shall meet the minimum requirements and standards for occupancy to provide for the safe and sanitary maintenance of said properties. 
( Ord. of 02-07-2017(2) ) 
Sec. 18-110. - Definitions. 
    The following words and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meaning ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Agent means agent, manager or other individual or entity representing the owner of a rental dwelling or unit, and who may serve as a point of contact on inspections under this article. 
    Certificate means a certificate of inspection issued by the city. 
    City means the department of community development, or such other office or individual as may be designated by the city to administer all or any part of the inspection program under this article. 
    Owner means a person or other entity who owns the physical premises occupied by the rental unit. 
    Property maintenance code means the international property maintenance code, as adopted by the mayor and board of aldermen, and enforced by the city pursuant to local ordinances. All definitions contained in the property maintenance code shall be applicable to this article. 
    Rental dwelling means any dwelling which is in whole or in part occupied by a person pursuant to an oral or written agreement for monetary or in-kind compensation but who are not acquiring an ownership interest in the house. These shall include single-family dwellings, two-family dwellings, multi-family dwellings or other rooming houses or boarding houses, and shall include the following as defined in the land development ordinance: 
(1)  Rooming house means any dwelling, or part of any dwelling containing one or more rooming units, in which space is let by the owner or operator to three or more persons who are not husband or wife, son or daughter, mother or father, or sister or brother of the owner or operator, and where the occupants share common bathroom, cooking and eating facilities.; and 
(2)  Rooming unit means any room used or intended to be used for sleeping purposes. 
    Tenant means any person, other than a legal or equitable title holder or immediate family member, occupying or possessing a dwelling or part thereof. 
( Ord. of 02-07-2017(2) ) 
Sec. 18-111. - Registration. 
(a)  All existing residential rental dwellings or units shall be registered with the city prior to June 1, 2017 and subsequently by June 1 of each year after 2017. All newly constructed or newly converted residential rental units shall be registered within ten days of the finished construction or conversion. 
(b)  An inspection fee of $10.00 for each rental dwelling or unit with an expired certificate of inspection shall be paid to the city at the time of registration and prior to the inspection being scheduled or performed. 
(c)  To register a residential rental dwelling or unit, the owner shall provide the following information on forms provided by the city: 
(1)  The name, address and telephone number of the owner and agent if applicable. 
(2)  The street address of the rental dwelling or unit along with other identification if more than one rental dwelling has the same street address. 
(3)  The number of bedrooms in each rental unit. 
(4)  Such other information as is reasonably required by the city. 
(d)  Each owner shall be required to notify the city within 30 days if there has been a change of information provided on the registration form. 
( Ord. of 02-07-2017(2) ) 
Sec. 18-112. - Certificate of inspection. 
(a)  No residential rental dwelling or unit shall be occupied without a valid certificate of inspection. 
(b)  A valid certificate of inspection shall be transferrable when the owner of a residential rental dwelling or unit changes. The new owner is still required to re-register the dwelling or unit as provided in section 18-111 herein. 
(c)  A certificate of inspection shall expire 12 months from the date of its issuance. 
(d)  Occupied rental units without a valid certificate of inspection after September 1, 2017 shall be in violation of section 18-112(a) herein. 
( Ord. of 02-07-2017(2) ) 
Sec. 18-113. - Inspections. 
(a)  Before issuing a certificate of inspection, the city shall inspect the residential rental dwelling or unit. The owner or agent shall be present during the inspection. It is the responsibility of the owner or agent to inform the tenants of the day and time when an inspection is scheduled. 
(b)  The city shall schedule inspections of all residential rental dwellings or units for the purpose of determining compliance with the property maintenance code and other city ordinances, codes and regulations. The city shall contact the owner or agent of each property to arrange an inspection at a mutually convenient time during regular city business hours, but not more than 30 days from the date of the first notification to the owner or agent that an inspection is desired. 
(c)  If city does not find the residential rental dwelling or unit in compliance with the property maintenance code during a scheduled inspection, the owner or agent will be furnished with a written list of deficiencies that shall be corrected before a certificate of inspection can be issued. 
(d)  Nothing under this section shall restrict the city from scheduling additional inspections when a complaint is filed or the city otherwise has reasonable suspicion to believe the dwelling or unit is in violation of the property maintenance code. The city also reserves the right to revoke an issued certificate of inspection in the event that a violation is found to exist. 
(e)  A property owner may request an inspection prior to the expiration of a current certificate of inspection. 
(f)  The inspections herein provided may be made by the occupancy inspector, building inspector, code enforcement officer, building official or any such other person designated by the city to make inspections and enforce this article. 
(g)  The fee for any inspection is $10.00 and must be paid to the city at the time it is scheduled and prior to the inspection being performed. Failed inspections or re-inspections shall result in an additional inspection fee. 
( Ord. of 02-07-2017(2) ) 
Chapter 22 - BUSINESSES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Local privilege taxes generally, MCA 1972, § 27-17-1 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 22-1. - Display of merchandise, goods, or wares outside of places of business. 
(a)  Prohibited acts. 
(1)  It shall be unlawful for any business owner, tenant, or occupant to display merchandise, goods, or wares outside of their respective places of business without special approval by the mayor and board of aldermen. Said approval shall only be given for special community sponsored events. 
(2)  At no time shall businesses display or store items on the exterior of their place of business such as clothing, shoes, hair products and other similar products except during said approved special community sponsored events. 
(b)  Exempted businesses. The mayor and board of aldermen, recognize that by nature, some business uses require outdoor storage and sales. The following business uses shall be exempt from the requirements of this article provided that all merchandise, goods or wares stored or displayed shall be kept clean and free from litter and that said storage or display shall not be located on any public right-of-way or within any traffic sight distance area. Exempt business uses are as follows: 
(1)  Agricultural equipment sales. 
(2)  Automobile, RV, trailer or truck sales. 
(3)  Holiday display sales. 
(4)  Horticultural and landscaping sales. 
(5)  Loose material sales such as dirt, gravel, asphalt or concrete. 
(6)  Lumber and home supplies sales. 
(7)  Portable or storage building sales. 
(8)  Small equipment sales. 
(9)  Utility sales and service. 
(10)  Other similar business uses. 
(Ord. of 12-2-2014, §§ 1, 2) 
Secs. 22-2-22-20. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - SLOT AMUSEMENT MACHINE LICENSE TAX 

Sec. 22-21. - Tax levied. 
    Pursuant to MCA 1972, § 27-27-5, there is levied within the city the tax allowed by such statute. The provisions of the Slot Amusement Machine Tax Law (MCA 1972, § 27-27-1 et seq.) are adopted by reference in this section as if fully set out in this section and made applicable to slot amusements machines as therein defined. 
(Code 1996, § 22-25; Ord. of 12-6-1994, § 1) 
Sec. 22-22. - Administrative provisions. 
    The tax collector is authorized to secure and provide such forms and stickers as may be necessary for enforcement of this article, and all appropriate municipal personnel are authorized and directed to carry out the provisions of this article and statutes. 
(Code 1996, § 22-26; Ord. of 12-6-1994, § 2) 
Sec. 22-23. - Payment of tax required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to place on location any machine subject to this article in this city without paying the tax levied pursuant to law, and such violation shall be punishable as a misdemeanor. 
(Code 1996, § 22-27; Ord. of 12-6-1994, § 3) 
Secs. 22-24-22-49. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - TRANSIENT DEALERS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Municipal authority to regulate transient vendors, MCA 1972, § 21-19-35; transient vendors, MCA 1972, § 75-85-1 et seq. 

Sec. 22-50. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Transient business means any business conducted for the sale of merchandise or services that is carried on at a particular location for a period of less than six months in each year, even though the owner of such business may conduct the business at another location for more than six months in each year. 
    Transient dealers means and includes all persons, both principals and agents, who engage or conduct in this city either in one locality or in traveling from place to place, a temporary or transient business of selling or soliciting orders for the sale of goods, wares or merchandise with the intention of continuing in such business in the city for a period of not more than 180 days, and who rent, lease, use or occupy, either in whole or in part, for the purpose of carrying on such business use, any room, building or other public or privately-owned building, any lot or parcel of land, any motor vehicle including trucks and semitrailers for the exhibition and sale of such goods, wares and merchandise. 
    Transient vendor means any person who transacts transient business in this state either in one locality or by traveling from place to place in this state. The term includes a vendor who for the purposes of carrying on such business hires, leases, uses or occupies any building, structure, motor vehicle, railroad car or real property. 
(Code 1996, § 22-86; Ord. of 12-7-1982, § 1(a)) 
Sec. 22-51. - Violations. 
    Any violation of any provision of this article is a misdemeanor and punishable as provided by law. 
(Code 1996, § 22-96; Ord. of 12-7-1982, § 3) 
State Law reference- Punishment, MCA 1972, § 75-85-19. 
Sec. 22-52. - Exemptions. 
(a)  The provisions of this article shall not apply to: 
(1)  Civic and nonprofit organizations or wholesale sales to retail merchants by commercial travelers; 
(2)  Wholesale trade shows or conventions; 
(3)  Sales of goods, wares, services or merchandise by sample, catalogue or brochure for future delivery; 
(4)  Fairs and convention center activities conducted primarily for amusement or entertainment; 
(5)  Any general sale, fair, circus, auction or bazaar sponsored by a church or religious organization; 
(6)  Garage sales held on premises devoted to residential use; 
(7)  Sales or repairs of crafts or sales or repairs of items made by hand by the person making the crafts or items; 
(8)  Duly licensed flea markets operating from a fixed location; 
(9)  Sales of agricultural, dairy, poultry, seafood or forest management products or services related to forest management or silvicultural activities, nursery products, foliage plants or ornamental trees, except such products or services sold at retail and not grown or produced within this state; 
(10)  Sales of agricultural services. 
(b)  A transient vendor not otherwise exempted from this article is not exempted from this article because of a temporary association with a local dealer, auctioneer, trader, contractor or merchant, or by conducting the transient business in connection with or in the name of any local dealer, auctioneer, trader, contractor or merchant. 
(Code 1996, § 22-87) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, MCA 1972, § 75-85-3. 
Sec. 22-53. - Compliance; authority of board of aldermen. 
    It shall be unlawful for any transient dealer to sell or exhibit for sale either at public or private sale any goods, wares or merchandise without first complying with the provisions of this article, or to make any false statements in reference to the matters required in this article above, or to fail or refuse to comply with the requirements of any of the provisions of this article. Every person, whether principal or agent, who by circular, handbill, newspaper, poster or in any manner advertises such sales as herein contemplated before proper license is issued to such transient dealer and before he has complied with the provisions of this article, shall be guilty of a violation of this article. Provided, however, that nothing in this article shall be construed as abridging or denying the right and power of the board of aldermen to refuse or withhold the granting of any license or to revoke the same, if granted, to a transient dealer upon any hearing thereof when in the discretion of the board on the basis of the disclosures as aforesaid, or from other information deemed by them sufficient, such action may be deemed necessary or proper to protect or safeguard the public from imposition, mischief or fraud. 
(Code 1996, § 22-88; Ord. of 12-7-1982, § 1(g)) 
Sec. 22-54. - License fee. 
    All transient dealers shall pay a license fee in the amount established by the city. 
(Code 1996, § 22-89; Ord. of 12-7-1982, § 1) 
Sec. 22-55. - Application. 
    At least 20 days prior to holding of a sale or solicitation under this article, every such transient dealer shall furnish to the administrative officer a verified license application setting out the following: 
(1)  Name and address of the applicant and also the name of the true owner if the applicant is not such true owner of the goods, wares or merchandise to be sold. 
(2)  Name, location and time of the proposed sale or solicitation. 
(3)  Inventory of the goods, wares or merchandise, on hand and on order, which the applicant intends to offer for sale at such sale. The inventory shall show the quantity, kind or grade of each item, the wholesale cost thereof, the price at which each item is proposed to be sold and the total wholesale and retail value of the inventory based on the foregoing, and, if sales are to be made other than from inventory, a copy of the catalogue or other sales materials, or a listing of the samples to be displayed. 
(4)  A statement of the amount of gross receipts realized from each sale conducted in the city by the applicant and the date thereof if such sale was within the preceding five years. 
(5)  Such other information as the administrative officer may prescribe. 
(6)  Address of any permanent place of business in the state, or, if there is no permanent place of business in the state, a copy of a certificate of the secretary of state evidencing the fact that the dealer has qualified to do business in the state and the name and address of its agent for the service of process in the state. 
(Code 1996, § 22-90; Ord. of 12-7-1982, § 1(b)) 
Sec. 22-56. - Deposits and bond. 
    The applicant shall also execute a cash bond or a surety bond issued by a corporate surety authorized to do business in this state in an amount that is the lesser of either $2,000.00 or five percent of the wholesale value of any merchandise or service to be offered for sale by the applicant. The surety bond shall be issued in favor of the state and shall be conditioned upon payment of all taxes due from the applicant to the state or to a political subdivision of the state; any fines assessed against the applicant or the applicant's agents or employees for a violation of this article; and any judgment rendered against the applicant or the applicant's agents or employees in a cause of action commenced by a purchaser of merchandise or services not later than one (year after the date the merchandise or services were sold by the applicant. The transient vendor shall maintain the bond during the period that the vendor conducts business in the city and for a period of one year after the termination of the business. After the transient vendor furnishes satisfactory proof to the county tax collector or municipal tax collector, as the case may be, that the vendor has satisfied all claims of purchasers of merchandise from or services offered by the vendor and that all sales taxes and other applicable taxes have been paid, the bond shall be released. The bond set forth in this section and certificate of qualification to do business in the state shall be public records open to examination upon request and copies thereof shall be furnished on request upon payment of a fee in the amount established by the city. 
(Code 1996, § 22-91; Ord. of 12-7-1982, § 1(c)) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, MCA 1972, § 75-85-13. 
Sec. 22-57. - Statement for certain sales. 
    A transient dealer shall not advertise, represent or hold forth a sale of goods, wares, or merchandise as an insurance, bankrupt, insolvent, assignee, trustee, estate, executor, administrator receiver, manufacturer's wholesale, cancelled order or misfit sale or closing-out, or a sale of any goods damaged by smoke, fire or water otherwise, unless before so doing he shall state in writing under oath to the administrative officer at the time he makes application for a license all the facts relating to the reason and character of such special sales, so advertised, held forth or represented, including a statement of the names of persons from whom such goods, wares or merchandise were purchased, and the date of delivery of same to the person applying for license, the place where said goods, wares or merchandise were taken last, and such details necessary to exactly locate and fully identify all goods, wares or merchandise to be sold, and make such further disclosure to and give such information as may be required by the administrative officer. Such transient dealer shall also include in such statement names and residences of the owners in whose interest the business is conducted and whether conducted as an individual, firm, association or corporation. 
(Code 1996, § 22-92; Ord. of 12-7-1982, § 1(f)) 
Sec. 22-58. - Reports of sales. 
    All transient dealers shall make a verified report of sales within seven days of the close of business. 
(Code 1996, § 22-93; Ord. of 12-7-1982, § 1(d)) 
Sec. 22-59. - Sunday sales. 
    No sales of goods, wares or merchandise shall be made on a Sunday by a transient dealer licensed hereunder unless otherwise permitted by law. 
(Code 1996, § 22-94; Ord. of 12-7-1982, § 1(e)) 
State Law reference- Authority to prohibit Sunday sales, MCA 1972, § 21-19-39. 
Sec. 22-60. - Nonwaiver of other fees, etc. 
    Nothing contained in this article shall be construed to relieve any person from any license fee liability, tax liability, interest, penalty or forfeiture incurred as of the effective date of the ordinance from which this article is derived. 
(Code 1996, § 22-95; Ord. of 12-7-1982, § 2) 
Secs. 22-61-22-78. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - SECONDHAND GOODS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Mississippi Pawnshop Act, MCA 1972, § 75-67-301 et seq. 

Sec. 22-79. - Records. 
    Every junk dealer and salvage operator in the city is required to keep accurate records in writing of each purchase and sale or delivery of each item of personal property involved in such transaction. Such records shall show the name of the person selling any article purchased by such dealer or operator, a physical description and residence, description of the article or articles and the amount paid therefor. When an item is brought into such shop, it shall have a number or identification of purchase placed on it at the time of the original transaction and corresponding to a record of the name of the person presenting it. This number shall remain on the item the whole time it is in the shop and until it is sold or redeemed or delivered to another person. When such item is sold or delivered to any other person, the name and address of the party or parties who purchased or received such item shall be recorded, corresponding to the number of the item delivered to such person. The records aforesaid shall be subject to inspection by the law enforcement officers of this city at any time. Any person failing to make such records and make them available for the required inspection shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and punishable for such misdemeanor as provided by law. 
(Code 1996, § 22-126; Ord. of 11-3-1992(1), § 1) 
Sec. 22-80. - Restriction of purchases. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to purchase, buy, barter or otherwise take the following items from a minor: rubber tires, scrap or junk rubber of any kind, old irons, sacks, watches, jewelry, bicycles, automobile and farm equipment parts, lawnmowers, machinery, tools, plumbing supplies, water pipe, water pipe fixtures, guns, pistols, knives, electric wire, electronic or radio equipment, electric fittings, or lead, brass and copper of every description, unless the person purchasing, buying, bartering or otherwise acquiring such article or part thereof shall first obtain from the parent or guardian of such minor his written consent to purchase, buy, barter, or otherwise acquire said article. If the minor is a person that either has no lawful guardian, or lives apart from his parents, then the matter must be submitted to the chief of police, who shall investigate the circumstances and if there is no evidence of fraud, shall give his written permission approving the purchase, sale, barter or acquiring of such article. 
(Code 1996, § 22-127; Ord. of 7-11-1967, § 1) 
Sec. 22-81. - Record of purchases. 
    Any person receiving the written permission required from the parent, lawful guardian or chief of police authorizing any of the aforementioned transactions shall keep the same on file in his place of business, or residence if he has no place of business, which such permission shall be retained for one year from the date of the transaction, and shall be, at all times, open to the inspection and examination of the police officers of this city. 
(Code 1996, § 22-128; Ord. of 7-11-1967, § 2) 
Secs. 22-82-22-105. - Reserved 
ARTICLE V. - STREET SALES OF ICE CREAM PRODUCTS 

Sec. 22-106. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Ice cream means any ice cream or any frozen ice product intended for immediate consumption. 
(Ord. of 6-5-2012(1), § 1) 
Sec. 22-107. - Requirements. 
    Any person who shall engage in the sale of ice cream on the public streets of this city shall obtain the proper municipal privilege or other applicable licenses, shall comply with all regulations of the state or county health departments applicable thereto, shall maintain the permanent site of all vehicles used in such distribution and sales within the city and shall maintain personal and property damage liability insurance of $250,000.00, or more, on each motor vehicle used for such sales, and shall furnish certificate of such insurance with the application for the city licenses aforesaid. Lapse or failure to maintain such insurance shall immediately terminate any licenses or permits theretofore issued. The owner or operator shall immediately notify the city clerk when the insurance coverage ceases for any reason. It is understood that the owner's or operator's failure to notify the clerk that the insurance coverage is not in effect is a separate violation of this article. 
(Ord. of 6-5-2012(1), § 2) 
Sec. 22-108. - Parking and vehicle maintenance. 
    No vehicle or vehicle with attached trailer used in such distribution shall be parked without its driver or operator, or overnight, upon or within the right-of-way of any public street, alley, sidewalk or walkway. The owner or operator of any such vehicle or vehicle with attached trailer shall maintain same in mechanical condition meeting all safety, pollution and noise requirements, and in physical appearance fully painted without rust or damaged surfaces. 
(Ord. of 6-5-2012(1), § 3) 
Sec. 22-109. - Location of sales. 
    No such sales, or stopping or parking therefor, shall take place: 
(1)  Within any school zone indicated by the city's or state's uniform traffic signals, or within 300 feet of any school campus, excluding from such measurement any street right-of-way where no such zone is indicated; 
(2)  Within 50 feet of any intersection; 
(3)  Within or upon any street without sufficient width of the lane within which such vehicle shall stop or park to leave available not less than ten feet of the width of the roadway lane for free movement of vehicular traffic; 
(4)  Within any four lane street or roadway; 
(5)  Without the intermittent flashing of standard hazard lights at the front and rear of the vehicle in use when stopped or moving slowly in the roadway; 
(6)  In any manner that constitutes a hazard or danger to any other vehicle, passenger or person whatsoever; or 
(7)  In any parking lot without the specific permission of the landowner. 
(Ord. of 6-5-2012(1), § 4) 
Secs. 22-110-22-145. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - MOBILE FOOD VEHICLES AND VENDING[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. of 06-05-2018(1) , §§ 1-5, adopted June 5, 2018, amended the former Art. VI, §§ 22-146-22-153, in its entirety, and enacted a new Art. VI as set out herein. The former Art. VI pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Ord. of 02-20-2017(1), § 1 . 

Sec. 22-146. - Definitions. 
    The following words and phrases, whenever used herein, shall be construed as defined in this section: 
    Catering trailers mean non-motorized apparatus pulled behind a vehicle in which food is prepared and stored and served for hire at events on private or governmental property at the direction of a private entity. 
    Mobile food vendor means any person who sells food and/or beverages (other than ice cream or frozen treats, the sales of which are regulated by separate ordinance) from a mobile pushcart or motorized mobile food preparation vehicle and whose sales occur at times and locations other than not-for-profit festivals sponsored by the chamber of commerce including Octoberfest and Crosstie Arts and Jazz Festival. Such festivals must be approved by the board of aldermen as promoting tourism and bringing favorable notice to the city. If a person sells food and/or beverages at any such not-for-profit festival sponsored by the chamber of commerce, then that person shall only be regulated by the chamber of commerce and shall not be subject to the requirements of this article. Mobile food vendors are not considered transient vendors and are subject only to the requirements of this ordinance for permitting and oversight. 
    Mobile pushcart means any portable vending device, pushcart or other wheeled vehicle or device which may be moved without the assistance of a motor and which is not required to be licensed and registered by the department of transportation, used for the displaying, storing or transporting of food (other than ice cream or frozen treats) offered for sale by a vendor. Said cart may be up to four feet in width, six feet in length, excluding auxiliary items such as handles or fenders, or otherwise the cart shall not occupy space greater than a total of 24 square feet. 
    Mobile food preparation vehicle means any motorized vehicle that includes a self-contained kitchen, with four enclosed walls, in which food is prepared, processed or stored and used to sell and dispense food to the consumer. The unit must be on wheels (excluding boats and trailers) at all times. This definition does not include pushcarts. This definition may include a catering trailer or a non-motorized device pulled behind a vehicle in which food is prepared and stored and which is not being utilized for a for hire event on private property or governmental property not regulated by the City of Cleveland provided said catering trailer meets each and every requirement of any other mobile food preparation vehicle authorized under this article. 
( Ord. of 06-05-2018(1), § 1 ) 
Sec. 22-147. - Permits required and requirements for mobile food vending. 
(a)  All mobile food vendors must obtain and maintain a permit for each location where the owner of the mobile pushcart or mobile food preparation vehicle intends to operate. All applications for permit renewal must be filed yearly and will be awarded on a first come first serve basis. The application shall be made with the department of community development. The application may be reviewed by any department of the city as may be necessary or convenient to determine whether the application is complete or whether the permit should be granted. Permit applications shall contain the following information: 
(1)  The name, mailing address, physical address, telephone number(s), and email address of the applicant(s). If any applicant is anything other than a natural person, then all documents related to the creation and maintenance of the entity such as articles of incorporation and any similar relevant documents shall be included. The applicant must state specifically where the mobile pushcart or food preparation vehicle intends to operate. 
(2)  A privilege license from the City of Cleveland or a privilege license from the town/city where the vendor's central kitchen is located. 
(3)  A food vending permit from the Mississippi Department of Health. 
(4)  A scaled sketch plan or photographs showing the proposed mobile pushcart or mobile food preparation vehicle, its dimension, and other details showing the proposed set-up of the push-cart or vehicle. 
(5)  A list of products to be sold. 
(6)  Proof of a valid insurance policy that provides minimum liability coverage of $500,000.00 per mobile food preparation vehicle and $250,000.00 per mobile pushcart, with the city named as an additional insured. 
(7)  A written indemnity agreement that will hold harmless the city, its officers, and employees, for any loss or liability or damage, including costs, for bodily injury or property damage sustained by a person as a result of the negligent installation, use, or maintenance of a permitted space. 
(8)  Copies of all letters and other notices from any governmental, quasi-governmental, professional, or business association or entity, related directly or indirectly to alleged or actual improper conduct in the food service business, issued to applicant or any person who will have responsibility for operations of the mobile pushcart or mobile food preparation vehicle for which a permit is requested. This shall include all related response and follow up documents showing any results, findings or actions. 
(9)  The dates, jurisdiction, court, and disposition of the following: 
a.  All felony charges related to the applicant or any principal of the applicant; and 
b.  All misdemeanors and violations directly or indirectly related to food, food preparation, permit operations, and/or business operations, related to the applicant or any principal of the applicant 
(10)  Approved inspection of vehicle by fire inspector. 
(11)  Such other additional information required by law, rule, or ordinance, or that any department of the city or city board of aldermen, or the permit applicant reasonably deems appropriate to assist the city in determining whether the permit should be granted. The applicant shall be provided reasonable time to supplement the application. 
(b)  No public vending permit or public vending management contract shall convey any interest in the real property under the jurisdiction of the City of Cleveland which is identified in any permit or contract and such permit shall only convey the right to use the property for the purposes allowed in this article. 
(c)  Permits cost $1000.00 per year for vendors with central kitchens located outside the City of Cleveland and $500.00 per year for vendors who have central kitchens/privilege licenses inside Cleveland's city limits; this cost covers the administrative cost of processing the application and regulating each mobile pushcart or mobile food preparation vehicle. 
(d)  Permit holders may be required to remove private materials or accessories to allow street, sidewalk, or utility access for emergency and maintenance operation or both. 
(e)  This permit does not allow permit holders to operate during city appointed special events without proper authorization from the special event organizers. 
(f)  The vendor shall not receive compensation for relocating. 
(g)  The permit must be displayed on the mobile pushcart or mobile food preparation vehicle at all times. 
(h)  Permits are non-transferable. 
(i)  A damaged or destroyed mobile pushcart or mobile food preparation vehicle may be replaced if and only if approval for its replacement is obtained from the department of community development. Any such replacement pushcart or vehicle must be of substantially the same type, size, and dimension and with the same general characteristics as the original. Such replacement may be disallowed if the original vendor permit would not have approved the use of the replacement pushcart or food preparation vehicle. 
(j)  Any permit granted pursuant to this article shall be nonexclusive. The city may grant any number of such permits as the city deems appropriate. The grant of a permit shall not limit or abridge any power or authority of the city and shall not limit the authority of the city to commence appropriate civil, criminal, or other enforcement actions. The city retains full authority to amend the ordinances, rules and regulations that apply to any permit. 
(k)  The city may revoke and terminate the permit in the event the vendor violates any term, condition, or provision of the permit, the Cleveland Code of Ordinances and/or zoning ordinances, state and/or federal law, or if the business license issued by the city for the permitted activity is revoked. The procedures for revoking or terminating a permit shall be the same as revoking or terminating a business license. The revocation may be sought as a remedy in a civil action. The vendor may terminate or surrender the permit at will any time prior to the expiration of the permit by providing written notice to the department of community development. Termination of the permit shall not operate to relieve the vendor of the obligation to release, hold harmless, and indemnify the city and its officers, agents, and employees. 
(l)  Permits shall be granted annually from January 1st-December 31st. Regardless of when the permit is issued, the cost shall remain the same for each applicant. In other words, there shall be no pro rata reduction in cost for permits granted after January 1st of each year or abandoned before December 31st of each year. The city reserves the right to limit the number of permits issued based on space availability. 
( Ord. of 06-05-2018(1), § 2 ) 
Sec. 22-148. - Location and operation. 
(a)  Mobile pushcarts and mobile food preparation vehicles shall only conduct business in designated areas approved by the department of community development. These areas currently include the City of Cleveland Food Truck Park located at Collins Street, a street located between South Chrisman and Commerce Streets. The city may also, at its sole discretion, issue permits to allow mobile pushcarts and mobile food preparation vehicles to conduct business on private property with the written permission of the owner of said property and where such a location shall not effect the requirement for parking for said property under the Land Development Ordinance, the city owned parking lot adjacent to and directly to the North of the No. 1 City of Cleveland Fire Station located on North Bayou Road and, for push-carts, city sidewalks located in the Crosstie Historic District or the B-2 Zoning District. For private property, the city will require a completed owner's affidavit, copies of which will be provided with a food vendor application. 
For mobile food vendors other than the owners of catering trailers used for private for hire events, the mobile food vendor is responsible for initiating a request to utilize such locations, and the department of community development shall have complete discretion as to which locations to approve considering the needs of traffic, pedestrians, public safety, public works, public convenience, the general uses of adjacent private property, and any other factor that is proper and lawful for the city to consider in approving or disapproving such locations. The department of community development shall have continuing authority to approve locations, grant conditions for approval, revoke prior approval of locations, make conditional revocations of approved locations, require adjustments by the mobile food vendor in setup or location to accommodate public safety and convenience, and to otherwise maintain full lawful control over all public ways of the city. The City of Cleveland Police and Fire Departments shall have concurrent authority to oversee locations and setup of mobile pushcarts and mobile food preparation vehicles. If an applicant is denied and wishes to appeal his grievance, he may request an appeal before the mayor and board of aldermen at a regular scheduled meeting. 
(b)  Catering trailers, mobile pushcarts and mobile food preparation vehicles shall conform to the following regulations regarding location and operation: 
(1)  Catering trailers, mobile pushcarts and mobile food preparation vehicles must be located at least 150 feet in all directions from the entrance to any non-mobile business selling food unless the owner of the other business gives written permission for the infringement of the no-vending area. Proof of said permission must be filed with the signs and licenses division. 
(2)  Catering trailers, mobile pushcarts and mobile food preparation vehicles must not be locked or attached to trees, garbage receptacles, or street furniture. 
(3)  Catering trailers, mobile pushcarts on public sidewalks shall not be located within three feet of a building or structure and mobile food preparation vehicles may not be located within 20 feet of a building or structure. 
(4)  Catering trailers, mobile pushcarts and mobile food preparation vehicles may not locate within any area which would block the view of traffic or traffic signals or traffic signs. 
(5)  Catering trailers, mobile pushcarts and mobile food preparation vehicles may not locate within ten feet of any fire hydrant. 
(6)  Catering trailers, mobile pushcarts and mobile food preparation vehicles must conform to all other applicable guidelines of the city's land development ordinance. 
(c)  In no event shall any catering trailers, mobile pushcart or mobile food preparation vehicle, display device, or accessory container be located inside any public building or structure or at any place the general public is prohibited. 
(d)  Mobile pushcarts and mobile food preparation vehicles may only be operated between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 10:00 p.m. Cleanup and removal of the pushcart or vehicle must be completed by 10:30 p.m. 
(e)  The operators must be present at all times. 
(f)  Mobile food vendors are responsible for all waste and trash removal. The containment area must be kept clear of grease, trash, paper, cups or cans associated with the operation. No liquid waste or grease is to be disposed of in tree pits or onto sidewalks, streets, or other public places. 
(g)  The mobile food vendor shall not provide stands, shelves, bins, equipment, signs, covers, or any kind of accessory or feature unless the same was accurately described and included in the application, and was fairly included in the picture or other graphics required as party of the application. 
(h)  The mobile food vendor shall contain all refuse, trash and litter within the mobile food service unit or within a small moveable trash can maintained by the vendor, and located adjacent to the mobile pushcart or mobile food preparation vehicle in such a manner as not to block or otherwise obstruct pedestrian or vehicular traffic. The vendor shall be responsible for the proper disposal of such refuse, trash, and litter, and shall place it in the public trash container, or in any private container with proper permission. The vendor is responsible for all litter and trash within 15 feet of the mobile pushcart or mobile food preparation vehicle at any time the vendor is selling or offering to sell any merchandise or service. 
(i)  The mobile pushcart or mobile food preparation vehicle must have self-contained utilities and shall not use the city's utilities or private utilities that are not self contained and integral to the vendor unit. Vendors shall, at all times, abide by the terms of the city's sewer use ordinance and specifically agrees to abide by the terms of said ordinance for the disposal of any grey water generated by the food vending vehicle or pushcart. 
(j)  No mobile food vendor shall sell or attempt to sell any item to the occupant of any motor vehicle, unless it is parked in a lawful parking space. 
(k)  Every mobile food vendor shall keep records utilizing generally accepted accounting practices for the purposes of compliance with all federal, state and local tax laws. 
(l)  All approved mobile pushcarts and mobile food preparation vehicles must pay the nine percent sales tax required by all food providers in the City of Cleveland, along with all other tax and licensing fees required by the State of Mississippi. 
(m)  All approved mobile pushcarts and mobile food preparation vehicles must be licensed businesses within the City of Cleveland with all operations pertinent to the mobile pushcart or vehicle operated within the City of Cleveland. 
(n)  All mobile pushcarts and mobile food preparation vehicles must be issued a State tax number by the Mississippi Department of Revenue designating them as a City of Cleveland business. 
( Ord. of 06-05-2018(1), § 3 ) 
Sec. 22-149. - Design standards for mobile pushcarts and food prep vehicles. 
    All mobile pushcarts and mobile food preparation vehicles must meet the following design standards: 
(1)  All mobile pushcarts and mobile food preparation vehicles must be self contained. This requires that the pushcart or food preparation vehicle is not connected or attached to any building or structure, and does not receive power from any building by means of wires, hoses, or other connections. The mobile food preparation vehicle must have four enclosed walls and service of food must be made from inside the enclosed walls to the public. 
(2)  Umbrellas or canopies must be attached to the pushcart or vehicle and must not exceed eight feet in height above grade. Maximum diameter of canopies and umbrellas shall not exceed six feet and shall not interfere with pedestrian movement. No mobile pushcart or mobile food preparation vehicle shall have more than two umbrellas. 
(3)  Signage on mobile pushcarts shall be no greater than 12 square feet and for mobile food preparation vehicles no greater than 32 square feet. No free standing signage is permitted. 
(4)  Mobile pushcarts and mobile food preparation vehicles must comply with all local, state, and federal rules regarding sanitation and protection of food from airborne contamination. 
(5)  Sales of goods are limited to food and beverage. 
(6)  Mobile food preparation vehicles may place a maximum of three coolers within their containment area so long as the coolers are neatly stacked to avoid visual clutter. Mobile pushcarts are not permitted to have coolers independent of their pushcart. 
(7)  No accessory container shall be more than three feet from the unit. 
(8)  Accessory containers must be made of hard substances such as hard plastic or a metal and may not be made by expanded polystyrene plastic, paper, paperboard, or cardboard. 
(9)  Two chairs are permitted for the vendor's use. 
(10)  Mobile pushcarts and mobile food preparation vehicles may not be stored, parked or left overnight on city property. 
(11)  All permit applicants must operate an existing licensed restaurant within the City of Cleveland or have a central kitchen approved by the Mississippi Department of Health for food service. 
(12)  All mobile food vendors shall operate at a decibel level that is not considered a public nuisance and is in compliance with any City of Cleveland Noise Ordinance regulations. In no event shall the decibel level generated by the mobile food vendor exceed 80Dba. No mobile food vendor shall use or maintain any outside sound amplifying equipment, lights or noisemakers, such as bells, horns or whistles to attract customers. 
(13)  All Mobile food preparation vehicles shall have at least one ABC extinguisher with a minimum classification of 2A:10BC rating. If grease laden vapors are produced in the vehicle, then a Class K rated portable extinguisher shall be required. Mobile food preparation vehicles are also generally subject to a fire inspection by the City of Cleveland. 
( Ord. of 06-05-2018(1), § 4 ) 
Sec. 22-150. - Violations and penalties for all vendors in this article. 
(a)  The following penalties apply to all vendors addressed in this article. For any violation, the vendor shall receive: 
(1)  First, a verbal or written warning from the city. 
(2)  If the vendor does not comply after such warning, the 
vendor  shall be fined $300.00 for the violation and, at the discretion of the City of Cleveland, a cease and desist notice may be issued. 
(b)  Any offense shall be considered a misdemeanor and is subject to being cited by any authorized law enforcement official in the City of Cleveland or with authority to do so in the City of Cleveland. 
(c)  Violation of this article may result in the suspension or revocation of any city permit or license issued to the owner or operator of the mobile pushcart or mobile food preparation vehicle, at the total discretion of the city. 
(d)  Each day on which an infraction of the ordinance occurs shall be considered a separate and distinct violation. 
(e)  All fines collected shall go to the city's general fund. 
( Ord. of 06-05-2018(1), § 5 )

Chapter 30 - FIRE PREVENTION AND PROTECTION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Authority to enact fire regulations, MCA 1972, § 21-19-21. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 30-1-30-18. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - FIRE CODES 

Sec. 30-19. - Scope. 
    The provisions of this article shall apply equally to both public and private property, and it shall apply to all structures and their occupancies, except as otherwise specified. 
(Ord. of 5-3-2005, § 13) 
Sec. 30-20. - Penalty.
