(5)  The beneficial effects of maintaining minimum standards of cleanliness, safety and sightliness for properties in the city include, but are not limited to, appreciation of property values, physical improvements of residential, commercial and industrial zones, attraction of capital investors to residential, commercial and industrial zones, increase in commercial trade and industrial productivity and increase in the tax base of the city; 
(6)  The abatement of such conditions will improve the general welfare, health, safety, appearance and image of the city; 
(7)  The abatement procedures set forth in this chapter are reasonable and afford due process to all affected persons; 
(8)  The uses and abuses of property, as described in this chapter, reasonably relate to the proper exercise of police power to protect the health, safety and welfare of the public. 
(Ord. of 6-6-2006, § 1) 
Sec. 46-4. - Unlawful property nuisance. 
    It is unlawful for any person owning, renting, leasing, occupying, managing or having charge, or possession of any real property in the city to maintain such premises in such a manner that any of the following conditions are found to exist thereon: 
(1)  A building, structure or portion thereof, which is in a dilapidated or dangerous condition so as to be unfit, unsafe or unsuitable for human occupancy. Such conditions include, but are not limited to: 
a.  Inadequate or inoperable mechanical, electrical, plumbing or sanitation systems or equipment; 
b.  Lack of sound and effective exterior walls or roof covering to provide adequate weather protection; 
c.  Lack of structural integrity, including deteriorated or inadequate foundations, joists, floors or parts thereof, vertical or horizontal support; 
d.  Broken, missing or inoperable windows or doors constituting a hazardous condition or a potential attraction to trespassers; 
e.  Buildings or structures which are unpainted or which otherwise lack sufficient exterior coating, causing dry rot, warping or termite infestation; 
f.  Broken, deteriorated or substantially defaced structures visually impacting on the neighborhood or presenting a risk to public safety; 
g.  Substandard building conditions described in the latest edition of the International Property Maintenance Code, International Building Code, International Residential Code, or International Fire Code. 
(2)  An abandoned building or structure such as: 
a.  An unoccupied and unsecured building or structure; 
b.  A partially constructed, reconstructed or demolished building or structure where work is abandoned for 120 consecutive days; 
c.  A damaged or partially destroyed building or structure not removed or repaired within 120 days after the damage or destruction, or, if the removal or repair cannot reasonably be accomplished within 120 days, upon which removal or repair has not been commenced within such period and prosecuted diligently toward completion. 
(3)  Property maintained in a condition so defective, unsightly or in a state of such deterioration, disrepair or neglect that it causes a health, safety or fire hazard or a public nuisance to children or others such as: 
a.  The accumulation of dirt, litter, refuse, trash or debris in carports, parking areas, driveways, front yards, side yards, rear yards, vestibules, buildings or doorways of buildings, the adjoining sidewalk or alley; 
b.  Storage of personal property (other than items designated for outdoor use) in front, exterior side or rear yard areas visible to public view, including, but not limited to, unregistered, inoperative or dismantled vehicles or vehicle parts, building materials not currently being used for the construction of improvements on the site, appliances, household furnishings or equipment, tools, machines, packing boxes, debris, rubbish, and broken or discarded furniture. 
(4)  Trees, weeds, grass, vines, brush or other vegetation which are dead, decayed, infested, diseased, overgrown or likely to harbor rats or vermin or which are detrimental to neighboring property or property values. 
(5)  Abandoned and broken equipment or machinery, or parts thereof. 
(6)  The discharge of sewerage or untreated water into any yard, open ditch, storm sewer line or any other open public or private property area. 
(7)  Fences or walls. 
a.  Which lack structural support because of missing or wet soil, missing or failed footings, or missing or failed fastenings; or which otherwise do not stand erect; 
b.  Which are in disrepair due to damage, crumbling mortar, missing bricks or wood, rotted wood, breaks or dents in their structure. 
(8)  A surface excavation or grading on private property which allows standing water and does not provide proper drainage and creates conditions favorable for the breeding and development of mosquito larvae. 
(9)  A vehicle which is inoperable, partially dismantled or abandoned and stored on any lot except behind a solid fence or wall a minimum of six feet in height or in a covered building. 
(10)  Waste matter or personal property placed on rooftops. 
(11)  Construction or agricultural equipment, machinery or materials, parked or placed on residential premises and visible from public property or an area open to the public; except during permitted construction, demolition or remodel work on the site. This restriction does not apply to residential areas located within A-1 (agricultural) zones. 
(12)  Any bus, commercial truck, trailer, boat trailer, construction equipment, recreational vehicle or agricultural equipment which is parked on the street right-of-way or on a lot or parcel in a residentially zoned district, unless the vehicle is in the process of delivering goods or services. 
(13)  Vehicle or vessel repair which occurs in a residentially zoned district and is offensive or detrimental to the health, safety or welfare of other persons, or which substantially interferes with the reasonable enjoyment of property by other persons, because of the substances, odors, noise or visual clutter created by the repair; or because of the items stored in connection with the repair, or because the repair is performed on a vehicle not owned by the occupant of the property. 
(14)  Any building or structure which is a public nuisance under common law. 
(15)  Any condition or activity which is a "nuisance" or a "public nuisance" as defined in by the State of Mississippi or which is specifically declared to constitute a nuisance by any state statute or by any city ordinance. 
(Ord. of 6-6-2006, § 3) 
Sec. 46-5. - Public nuisance declared. 
    All property found to be maintained in violation of any one or more of the provisions of section 46-4 is hereby declared to be a public nuisance and shall be abated pursuant to the procedures set forth herein. The procedures for abatement set forth herein shall not be exclusive and shall not in any manner limit or restrict the city from enforcing other city ordinances or abating public nuisances in any manner provided by law. 
(Ord. of 6-6-2006, § 4) 
Sec. 46-6. - Responsible for property maintenance. 
    Every responsible party who owns or is in possession of premises within the city is required to maintain such premises in a manner so as not to violate the provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. of 6-6-2006, § 5) 
Sec. 46-7. - Right to enter property to inspect or abate. 
    Any officer, employee or agent of the city may enter and inspect or abate any building or premises whenever necessary to secure compliance with, or prevent violation of, any provision of this chapter. If required by law, the officer, employee or agent shall first obtain consent of the responsible party or an appropriate court order. 
(Ord. of 6-6-2006, § 6) 
Sec. 46-8. - Abatement procedure. 
(a)  Determination; written order of compliance. Whenever the enforcement officer determines that any property is maintained in violation of one or more of the provisions of this chapter, he shall serve on one or more of the responsible parties a written compliance order which contains: 
(1)  The date and location of the violation; 
(2)  The section of the code violated and a brief description of the violation; 
(3)  The actions required to correct the violation or abate the condition such as: repair and rehabilitation, demolition, vacating occupants, cleaning and securing the structure and cleaning the front, side or rear yards; 
(4)  The date at which a public hearing is scheduled with the mayor and board of aldermen if the responsible parties should fail to abate the conditions set forth in the compliance order. 
(b)  Required action; compliance measures. The compliance order shall describe the action required to abate the public nuisance, which may include any or all of the following measures: 
(1)  Repair and rehabilitation. If the enforcement officer determines that the structure can be reasonably repaired, and the cost of repair has not exceeded 50 percent of the structure value, the compliance order shall require that the responsible person obtain all necessary permits immediately and begin the repair work within a specified time. The enforcement officer shall establish reasonable time frames to obtain permits and complete all repairs. 
(2)  Demolition. If the enforcement officer determines that the structure cannot be reasonably repaired within the guidelines established in the international property maintenance code, or that the cost of repair will exceed 50 percent of the structure value, the compliance order shall require that the responsible person obtain all necessary permits immediately and complete demolition within the period of time established by the enforcement officer. 
(3)  Vacation and notice to tenants. If the enforcement officer determines that vacation of the structure is necessary for demolition or repairs, the compliance order shall require the responsible person to expeditiously vacate the structure in accordance with applicable laws and within the period of time established by the enforcement officer. 
(4)  Clean and secure. If the front, side or rear yard of the property is in violation of any section set forth herein, the compliance order shall require the responsible person to clean the property and properly dispose of any debris. If the structure is vacant or abandoned before or during repairs, rehabilitation or demolition, or, after the tenants have vacated, the compliance order may require the responsible person to immediately clean and secure the property according to the procedures and standards outlined in section 46-9. 
(Ord. of 6-6-2006, § 7) 
State Law reference- Municipal cleaning of property MCA 1972, § 21-19-11. 
Sec. 46-9. - Emergency cleanup or abatement. 
    In order to enforce the provisions of this chapter, when the enforcement officer find and determine that the severity of the violation warrants immediate action, the enforcement officer may cleanup or abate the violation thereof. The cost of such cleanup or abatement may be recovered by the city in a civil action. Such emergency cleanup or abatement will not relieve the responsible party of further action which may be taken by the enforcement officer including, but not limited to, liability for any violations of this chapter or any other applicable provisions of state law and local ordinances. 
(Ord. of 6-6-2006, § 8) 
Sec. 46-10. - Non-emergency abatement time limits. 
    The compliance order shall state a time limit appropriate for the abatement of all non-emergency public nuisances. The enforcement officer is authorized to determine the time necessary for the efficient remedy of the violation, not to exceed 60 calendar days. The affected owner or responsible person may submit a written request for an extension of time to comply with the order if all of the following circumstances exist: 
(1)  The responsible person enters into an agreement to comply with the compliance order if allowed a specified additional amount of time; 
(2)  The extension of time will not create or perpetuate a situation that is dangerous to life or property; 
(3)  Circumstances that justify the delay are beyond the direct control of the responsible person; and 
(4)  The extension of time shall not exceed an additional 60 calendar days to complete the repairs, rehabilitation or demolition. 
(Ord. of 6-6-2006, § 9) 
Sec. 46-11. - Standards for boarding a vacant structure. 
    Securing any structure from unauthorized intrusion as required by a compliance order shall be in accordance with the following specifications and requirements: 
(1)  Remove all waste, rubbish or debris from the interior of the structure; 
(2)  Remove all waste, rubbish or excessive vegetation from the yards surrounding the vacant structure; 
(3)  Barricade all unsecured doorways, windows or exterior openings with minimum one-half inch thickness exterior grade plywood which shall extend to the molding stops or studs; 
(4)  Mount at least two wood stocks of minimum two- by four-inch thickness to the reverse face of the plywood with minimum three-eighths inch carriage bolts mated with nuts and two flat washers; 
(5)  Extend the stock a minimum of eight inches on each side of the interior wall; 
(6)  Cause all hardware to be galvanized or cadmium plated; 
(7)  Paint all exterior barricade material the predominant color of the structure; and 
(8)  Post the premises. One or more signs shall be posted at or near each entrance to the structure and on fences or walls as appropriate. The signs shall remain posted until the structure is either lawfully occupied or demolished. Signs shall contain the following information: 
DO NOT ENTER It is unlawful to enter or occupy this building or premises, or to remove or deface this notice. Trespassers will be prosecuted. City of Cleveland Code Compliance Department 843-5365.  
(Ord. of 6-6-2006, § 10) 
Chapter 50 - OFFENSES AND MISCELLANEOUS PROVISIONS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Crimes generally, MCA 1972, § 97-1-1 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 50-1. - Public indecency. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to willfully perform any of the following acts in a place where a person should reasonably expect to be in view of the public: 
(1)  An act or simulated act of sexual intercourse or masturbation; 
(2)  Exposure of the genitals; 
(3)  A lewd appearance in a state of partial or complete nudity; 
(4)  A lewd caress or indecent fondling of the body of another person; 
(5)  A lewd caress or indecent fondling of the sexual organs of any person, including oneself; 
(6)  Urination or defecation; or 
(7)  Appears wearing pants or skirts more than three inches below the top of the hips (crest of the ilium) exposing the skin or undergarments located above the waistband of said clothing. 
(b)  It is a defense under this section if it is determined, after a hearing or trial, that the person was exercising rights protected by the federal or state constitution. Any defense under this section must be asserted prior to any hearing or trial in the matter. 
(c)  The following penalties apply to this section: 
(1)  For violations of subsections (a)(1) through (6) of this section, a citation shall be issued to the offender and the person shall be subject to a penalty of not less than $500.00 for the first offense and six months in jail and for the second offense a penalty of $1,000.00 and six months in jail. 
(2)  For violations of subsection (a)(7) of this section, a citation shall be issued to the offender and the person shall be subject to a penalty of not less than $50.00 for the first offense and not more than $200.00 for a subsequent offense. In addition to the fine, the municipal court may order such person to participate in up to 40 hours of court approved community services activities. Violators shall not be subject to arrest or imprisonment for violation of this section, however, the municipal court shall have full authority to enforce its orders, judgments and sentences. 
(Ord. of 7-5-2012, §§ 1-3) 
Sec. 50-2. - False emergency alarms. 
(a)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Emergency alarm systems means an assembly of equipment or devices which is designed, arranged, installed or used for the detection of a hazardous condition or situation or an unauthorized entry or attempted entry into a building, structure and which emits a sound, or transmits a signal or message when activated, to which annunciation a law enforcement agency or other emergency service may be summoned to respond. Such system may hereinafter be referred to as "alarm system" or "E.A.S." and such designation may be used in any proceedings or circumstances of which it may be a subject. It is understood that this does not include alarm systems owned by the city when the systems are utilized on premises owned or operated by the city. The provisions of this section shall not be applicable to audible alarms affixed to automobiles nor to audible smoke detectors. 
    False alarm means the activation of an alarm system when no emergency exists through mechanical failure, malfunction, improper installation or through the negligence of the owner or user of the alarm system, which activation results in a response by the police or fire department or other emergency service agency. 
    Malicious false alarm means the intentional and false reporting to the police, fire or other emergency department of an emergency condition, or the intentional setting off of an alarm system which will be transmitted to, or which will cause another to report the signal to, the police, fire or other emergency service, and which setting off or reporting will call upon the such service to respond, when no emergency exists. However, this is not to include the testing of an alarm system by a licensed alarm business under guidelines established by the police, fire or other emergency service agency. This section shall not apply to the testing of alarms or alarm systems when the testing has been done in accordance with instructions or prescribed guidelines set by the police department or other emergency department and when the police or other emergency department has been given advance notice of such testing. 
    Notice means written notice, given by the issuance of a citation left at the scene from which a false alarm originated by officers of the police or fire departments, or given by U.S. mail addressed to the owner, lessee or other designated operator to be notified at his last known address. Service of such notice shall be effective upon the completion of personal service or upon the placing of the same in the custody of the U.S. Postal Service. 
(b)  Alarm transmitters and monitors. 
(1)  Where alarm transmitters are installed into receivers in the police, fire, or other emergency agency systems, the installer, monitor or other operator thereof, shall, in addition to the owner, lessee or other user of the system, be subject to the same requirements and penalties as herein provided, and such shall be deemed to be a separate entity at and for each location at and from which the alarm system is activated. 
(2)  For each emergency alarm system (E.A.S.) installed to transmit an alert or emergency signal into the police, fire or other emergency department, the installer shall provide such department information about the system, which shall include the name of the owner or occupant of the premises, the name and telephone number of the user or primary person and at least one alternate responsible for responding to the premises when the alarm is activated, and information concerning whether the alarm system includes an audible alarm. 
(c)  Violations. 
(1)  It shall be unlawful for the owner, installer, monitor or other operator or user of any emergency alarm system to allow or cause to any false alarm to be generated, transmitted or sent in any manner to the unit required to respond thereto. 
(2)  It shall be unlawful for any owner, installer, monitor or other operator, user or person to intentionally cause any malicious false alarm to be generated, transmitted or sent in any manner to the unit or units required to respond. 
(3)  Newly leased, rented, purchased or monitored alarms or alarm systems shall not be subject to the provisions of this ordinance relating to the counting and assessment of false alarms, other than malicious false alarms, for a period of 30 days from the date the alarm or alarm system becomes operational. The grace period provided in this subsection shall apply only if the alarm user notifies in writing the emergency department to whom the alarm is transmitted within ten days of the completion of installation or reinstallation. The written notice shall specify the date the system was installed or reinstalled. For reinstalled alarm systems, the notice shall also describe the nature and extent of the reinstallation. 
(d)  Penalties. 
(1)  For the violations herein, the user of a police, fire or other emergency alarm service shall pay the city a penalty of $25.00 for a false alarm received by the police or fire services division after a maximum of four false alarms have been received from the same police or fire emergency alarm system within any 12-month period. This shall not apply to any governmental entity in regards to payment of fee or penalty. 
a.  The fifth such alarm offense shall require the payment of a $25.00 penalty. 
b.  The sixth such alarm offense shall require the payment of a $50.00 penalty. 
c.  The seventh such alarm offense shall require the payment of a $75.00 penalty. 
d.  The eighth such alarm offense shall require the payment of an $800.00 penalty. 
e.  Such offenses in excess of eight shall require minimum penalties of amounts in increments of $25.00, or such amounts as may be lawfully imposed by the court of competent jurisdiction. 
(2)  Violations for malicious false alarm and other violations herein, including those of any user as provided in subsection (b)(1) of this section are misdemeanors. 
(e)  Failure to comply with citation tickets or notice. In the event any person fails to comply with a citation ticket by paying the penalty therein, or notice given to such person, or fails to make appearance pursuant to a summons directing an appearance in court, or if any person fails or refuses to deposit bail, as required, the clerk of the municipal court shall secure and issue a warrant for his arrest. 
(Ord. of 5-7-2002, §§ 1-5) 
Sec. 50-3. - Use or possession of tobacco by minors prohibited. 
(a)  The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Tobacco product means any tobacco cigarette, cigar, pipe tobacco, smokeless tobacco or any other form of tobacco or tobacco product which may be used for smoking, chewing, inhaling or ingesting by any other means. 
    Use or possession means the smoking of tobacco products, the chewing, oral consumption, spitting, inhaling or other ingestion of any tobacco product, or the possession of a cigarette, cigar or other tobacco product, or of any container of tobacco spittle. 
(b)  No person under 18 years of age shall have in his possession or use any tobacco product within the corporate limits of the city. 
(Ord. of 7-7-1998, §§ 1, 3) 
Secs. 50-4-50-24. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - OFFENSES AGAINST PUBLIC PEACE AND ORDER[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Municipal authority to preserve public peace and order, MCA 1972, §§ 21-19-15, 21-19-19. 

Sec. 50-25. - Curfew for minors. 
(a)  This section shall be known and may be cited as the "Nocturnal Curfew Ordinance." 
(b)  The mayor and board of aldermen hereby determines that large numbers of juveniles have been congregating in the city after dark causing general disturbances to residents and contributing to an excessive number of incidents of drug and alcohol related crimes, thefts, homicides and assaults, including a high proportion of crimes committed by and against juveniles. 
(c)  Said board finds and determines that special and extenuating circumstances presently exist within this city that call for special regulations of minors within the city in order to protect them from each other and from other persons on the street during the nocturnal hours, to aid in crime prevention, to promote parental supervision and authority over minors and to decrease incidents of nocturnal juvenile crime. 
(d)  In accordance with the prevailing community standards, this section serves to regulate the conduct of juveniles on streets during nocturnal hours, to be effectively and consistently enforced for the protection of the juveniles in this city from each other and from other persons on the streets during the nocturnal hours, for the enforcement of parental control of, authority over and responsibility for their children, for the protection of the public from nocturnal mischief by juveniles, for the reduction in the incidents of juvenile criminal activity and for the furtherance of family responsibility and for the public good, safety and welfare. 
(e)  The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning. When not inconsistent with the context, words used in the present tense include the future, words in the plural number include the singular, and words in the singular number include the plural. The word "shall" is always mandatory and not merely directory. 
    Minor or juvenile means any un-emancipated person under the age of 18 years, or in equivalent phrasing often herein employed, any person 17 or less years of age. 
    Parent means any person having legal custody of a minor: 
(1)  As a natural or adoptive parent; 
(2)  As a legal guardian; 
(3)  As a person to whom legal custody has been given by order of the court; or 
(4)  As a person, caretaker or other custodian responsible for the care or support of such minor. 
    Police department means the police department headquarters, or police station, located at the intersection of South Street and Sharpe Avenue, in the city. 
    Remain means to stay behind, to tarry and to stay unnecessarily upon the street, including the congregating of groups (or of interacting minors) totaling four or more persons in which any minor involved would not be using the streets for ordinary or serious purposes as mere passage or going home. To implement that thought with additional precision and precaution, numerous exemptions are expressly defined in subsection (h) of this section so that this is not a mere prohibitory or presence type curfew ordinance. 
    Street means a way or place, of whatsoever nature, open to the use of the public right for purposes of vehicular travel or, in the case of a sidewalk thereof, for pedestrian travel. The term "street" includes the legal right-of-way, including, but not limited to, the traffic lanes, the curb, the sidewalk, whether paved or unpaved and any grass, plots or other grounds found within the legal right-of-way of the street. The term "street" applies irrespective of what it is called or formally named, whether alley, avenue, court, circle or road, or dedicated or otherwise. 
    Time of night referred to herein is based upon the prevailing standard of time, whether central standard time or daylight savings time, generally observed at that hour by the public in the city, and prima facie the time when observed in the city administrative offices and the police department. 
    Year of age continues from one birthday, such as the seventeenth, to (but not including the day of) the next, making it clear that 17 or less years of age is herein treated as equivalent to the phrase "under 18 years of age." 
(f)  It shall be unlawful for any minor under 18 years of age to remain in or upon any public street, highway, park, vacant lot, parking lot or other public place, including private or commercial places and parking lots open to and intended for use by the public, within the city during the period ending at 6:00 a.m. and beginning at: 
(1)  12:00 midnight Saturday and Sunday morning (i.e., also referred to as being 12:00 midnight on Fridays and Saturdays); and 
(2)  11:00 p.m. on Sunday night through Thursday night. 
(g)  It shall further be unlawful for a parent of a minor to knowingly permit or by inefficient or ineffective control to allow such minor to be or remain upon any city street or other public place as provided in subsection (f) of this section under circumstances not constituting any exception to, or otherwise beyond the scope of, the curfew ordinance. The term "knowingly" includes knowledge which a parent should reasonably be expected to have concerning the whereabouts of a minor in that parent's legal custody. It is intended to continue to keep neglectful or careless parents up to a reasonable community standard of parental responsibility through an objective test. It shall, a fortiori, be no defense that a parent was completely indifferent to the activities or conduct or whereabouts of such minor child. 
(h)  The following shall constitute valid exceptions to the operation of the curfew: 
(1)  At any time, if a minor is accompanied by his parent. 
(2)  When accompanied by an adult authorized by a parent of such minor to take said parent's place in accompanying said minor for a designated period of time and purpose within a specified time. 
(3)  Until the hour of 12:30 a.m. if the minor is on an errand as directed by his parent. 
(4)  If the minor is legally employed, for the period from 45 minutes before to 45 minutes after work, while going directly between his home and place of employment. This exception shall also apply if the minor is in a public place during curfew hours in the course of his employment. To come within this exception, the minor must be carrying a written statement of employment issued by employer pursuant to authorization of the chief of police to expire within 90 days. 
(5)  Until the hour of 12:30 a.m. if the minor is on the property of, or the sidewalk directly adjacent to, the place where such minor resides or the place immediately adjacent thereto if the owner of the adjacent building does not communicate an objection to the minor and the police officer. 
(6)  When returning home by a direct route from, and within 30 minutes of the termination of, a school activity or an activity of a religious or other voluntary organization, or a place of public entertainment, such as a movie, play or sporting event. This exception will not apply beyond 1:30 a.m. If the event is not commercial in nature or does not have a fixed, publicly known time at which it will or does end, the sponsoring organization must register the event with the chief of police or his designated representative at least 24 hours in advance, informing the police department of the time such event is scheduled to begin, the place at which it shall be held, the time at which it shall end and the name of the sponsoring organization. 
(7)  In the case of reasonable necessity, but only after such minor's parent has communicated to the police department personnel the facts establishing such reasonable necessity relating to specified streets at a designated time for a described purpose, including place or origin and destination. A copy of such communication, or the police record thereof, duly certified by the chief of police or his designee, as aforesaid, to be correct, an appropriate notation of the time it was received and of the names and addresses of such parent and minor shall constitute evidence of qualification under this exception. 
(8)  When exercising first amendment rights protected by the United States Constitution, such as the free exercise of religion, freedom of speech and the right of assembly. Such minor shall evidence the bona fides of such exercise and provide notice to city officials by first delivering to the police department a written communication, signed by such minor, and countersigned if practicable by a parent of such minor, with their home address and telephone number, addressed to the mayor of the city, specifying when, where, and in what manner said minor will be on the streets at night (including hours when the curfew ordinance is still otherwise applicable to said minor) in the exercise of a first amendment right specified in such communication. 
(9)  When a minor is, with parental consent, in a motor vehicle engaged in bona fide interstate travel through the city, particularly on U.S. Highway 61 and State Highway 8, and access roads to these interstate systems. This also exempts all interstate travel beginning or ending in the city. 
(10)  Each of the foregoing exceptions, and their several limitations, such as provisions for notification, are severable, as hereinafter provided, but here re-emphasized. 
(i)  A police officer of the city who has probable cause to believe a minor is in violation of this section shall: 
(1)  Ascertain the name and address of the minor; 
(2)  Issue the minor a written warning that the minor is in violation of this ordinance; and 
(3)  Order the minor to go promptly home by a direct route. 
(j)  Notwithstanding subsection (i)(1) of this section, a police officer who has probable cause to believe that a minor is in violation of this section shall transport the minor to the police department if: 
(1)  The minor has received one previous written warning for violation of this section; or 
(2)  Reasonable grounds exist to believe the minor has engaged in delinquent conduct. 
(k)  When a minor is taken to the police department, the minor's parents shall be immediately contacted. If after this contact there is still probable cause to believe the minor was violating this section, the minor shall be held until the parent comes to take the minor home. When the parent arrives, he shall be given a copy of this section. If no parent has arrived within two hours, the minor may be turned over to custody of the local youth court authorities until a parent can take custody of him. 
(l)  Parental notification; violation and penalty. 
(1)  In case of a second violation by a minor, the chief of police shall, by certified mail, send to the minor's parent written notice of said violation with a warning that any subsequent violation will result in a full or penal enforcement of the curfew ordinance, including the enforcement of parental responsibility and of applicable penalties. Said notice shall be sent to the minor's parent at his or her last known address and evidence of its mailing shall constitute sufficient notice of the minor's violation. 
(2)  If, after the mailing of the warning notice set forth in subsection (l)(1) of this section, of a second violation by a minor, a parent violates subsections (f) or (g) of this section in connection with a third violation by a minor, this shall be treated as a first offense by the parent. For such first parental offense, a parent shall be fined $25.00. For each subsequent offense by a parent the fine shall be increased by an additional $25.00 (e.g., $50.00 for the second, and $75.00 for the third offense). 
(m)  Any minor who shall violate any of the provisions of this article for more than two times shall be dealt with according to the Youth Court Law of the state as an offender thereunder, and in accordance with the directives of the county youth court, or such other court as shall have jurisdiction of said minor. 
(Ord. of 4-6-2010, §§ 1-6) 
State Law reference- Punishment for violation of ordinances, MCA 1972, § 21-13-1. 
Sec. 50-26. - Disorderly houses. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to keep a disorderly house or to participate in a disorderly house by making, causing or allowing to be made therein, loud or improper noises, or by collecting therein drunken, noisy and disorderly persons, to include, but not limited to, loud music, crowds or groups of people that disturb the neighborhoods; persons loitering in yards, porches, driveways or streets; parking vehicles in yards or along streets adjacent to house which blocks or impedes traffic; or creates a hazard to traffic or public safety; or violates any zoning or other ordinances of the municipality; or any other conduct or activity which violates any other federal, state or municipal law. 
(b)  This section shall apply to single-family houses, apartments, duplexes, multi-family apartment complexes, mobile homes, or any other rental or owner occupied structure used for residential purposes. If any offense occurs, all adult persons who are either owners of the structure where the offense occurs, or any person who is a participant in the above referenced disorderly conduct or any tenant of the structure may be issued a citation. 
(c)  Conviction under this section shall constitute a misdemeanor and, upon conviction punishment, shall be administered and applied as follows: 
(1)  First offense shall result in a fine of $100.00, plus all applicable court costs and fees; 
(2)  Second offense within one year from the date of this first conviction shall result in a fine of $500.00, plus all applicable court costs and fees or ten days in jail, or both; 
(3)  Third offense within one year from the date of the first conviction shall result in a fine of $1,000.00, plus all applicable court costs and fees or 30 days in jail, or both. 
(d)  If the offender rents, occupies, lives, stays, sleeps or otherwise remains in the premises in whole or in part, upon conviction for the first offense, the municipal court clerk shall notify the owner/landlord by certified mail, return receipt requested, of the person's conviction under this article. Thereafter, the municipal court clerk shall give notice in the same manner to the owner/landlord on each occasion of the person's conviction of this offense. 
(e)  Upon the third conviction within one year, the municipal court clerk shall notify the director of zoning and enforcement for the city of the convictions at the location which the board of aldermen may consider to constitute a public nuisance a sufficient basis for the municipality to institute a removal or abatement proceeding against the premises as provided by law. 
State Law reference- Punishment for violation of ordinances, MCA 1972, § 21-13-1. 
Sec. 50-27. - Permit for amplification devices. 
(a)  Required. It shall be unlawful for any person to operate, or cause to be so operated, or to assist in operating, any sound amplification system, or any instrument that produces, or to otherwise produce or reproduce, any loud, or excessive, and raucous sounds, or sounds which rumble or otherwise sound disagreeable or disturbing, which system is within any vehicle, or portable, mobile or otherwise carried, in any street, park, parking lot or other place accessible to the public, and which sounds can be heard from a distance of 50 or more feet from the vehicle or device, without a permit otherwise properly issued therefor, unless such system, instrument or device is being operated as an alarm to request assistance or warn of a hazardous situation. 
(b)  Authorized emergency vehicles. This section shall not apply to authorized emergency vehicles responding to emergency calls or in the immediate pursuit of an actual or suspected violator of the law. 
(c)  Sound trucks and parades. This section shall not apply to sound amplification systems, devices, or instruments or systems upon sound trucks or vehicles in parades, processions, or public demonstrations, provided that the operator thereof obtains and operates such sound system, device, or instrument in accordance with any permit required by other provisions of the laws of this city. 
(Code 1996, §§ 46-26-46-28; Ord. of 11-3-1992(2), §§ 1-3) 
Secs. 50-34-50-57. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - OFFENSES AGAINST PUBLIC SAFETY 

Sec. 50-58. - Possession of firearms in parks, public meetings, political rallies and athletic events. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any individual knowingly to possess a firearm while in or about the following locations in the city: 
(1)  Public parks. 
(2)  At public meetings of the municipality, the county or other governmental body. 
(3)  At a political rally, parade or official political meeting. 
(4)  At a non-firearm-related school, college or professional athletic event. 
(b)  This section shall not apply to weapons in the possession of appointed, qualified and serving law enforcement. 
(c)  The city manager and/or any department heads are authorized and directed to cause to be posted signs conspicuously at each public entrance to each building or facility under the control of the municipality where public meetings are had by the municipality or other governmental body, advising the public that firearms are prohibited there during public meetings of the municipality and other governmental bodies. Signs stating firearms are prohibited should also be placed conspicuously at public parks under the municipalities' control. 
(Ord. of 6-3-2014, §§ II, III, V) 
State Law reference- Local firearms ordinances, MCA 1972, § 45-9-51 et seq. 
Sec. 50-59. - Aggressive panhandling. 
(a)  Panhandling defined any solicitation made in person upon any street, public place or park in the city, in which person requests an immediate donation of money or other gratuity from another person. 
(b)  Panhandling as defined by this ordinance does not prohibit any person from passively standing or sitting, performing music, singing or other street performance (provided such musical performances conform with the city's other ordinances) with a sign or indication that a donation is being sought with or without a vocal request which does not otherwise violate any provision of this ordinance. 
(c)  It is unlawful to engage in any panhandling when either the panhandler or the person being solicited is located in a vehicle which is moving, parked or stopped on a public street or alley, within 20 feet of an ATM machine or at any time after sunset or before sunrise or when the panhandler is standing in a public street attempting to receive a donation. 
(d)  It is also unlawful to engage in any aggressive panhandling which shall include: 
(1)  Touching the solicited person without the solicited person's consent; 
(2)  Panhandling when the person being solicited is walking up to their vehicle; 
(3)  Blocking the path of the person being solicited or the entrance to their vehicle or building being entered; 
(4)  Following behind, ahead or alongside the person being solicited who has walked away from the panhandler; 
(5)  Using profane or abusive language during any such attempt at panhandling; 
(6)  Continuing to panhandle at private residences after the panhandler has been told the resident is uninterested; 
(e)  Penalty. 
    Any person violating any of the provisions of this section shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor, and, upon conviction thereof, shall be fined no more than: 
$100.00 1st offense $250.00 2nd offense $500.00 3rd offense $1000.00 4th offense  
( Ord. of 01-10-2017(1) ) 
Editor's note- Ord. of 01-10-2017(1) , adopted January 1, 2017, added provisions to the Code, but did not specify manner of inclusion. Therefore, at the discretion of the editor, said provisions have been included as § 50-59 herein. 
Secs. 50-60-50-89. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - ANTI-LITTER REGULATIONS 

Sec. 50-90. - Short title. 
    This article shall be known and may be cited as the "City of Cleveland, Mississippi, Anti-Litter Ordinance." 
(Code 1996, § 46-81; Min. of 9-11-1962, § 1) 
Sec. 50-91. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning. When not inconsistent with the context, words used in the present tense include the future, words used in the plural number include the singular number, and words used in the singular number include the plural number. The word "shall" is always mandatory and not merely directory. 
    Aircraft means any contrivance now known or hereafter invented, used or designated for navigation or for flight in the air. The term "aircraft" shall include helicopters and lighter-than air dirigibles and balloons. 
    Authorized private receptacles means a litter storage and collection receptacle as required and authorized by the city ordinances. 
    Commercial handbill means any printed or written matter, any sample or device, dodger, circular, leaflet, pamphlet, paper, booklet or any other printed or otherwise reproduced original or copies of any matter or literature: 
(1)  Which advertises for sale any merchandise, product, commodity or thing; 
(2)  Which directs attention to any business or mercantile or commercial establishment or other activity, for the purpose of either directly or indirectly promoting the interest thereof by sales; 
(3)  Which directs attention to or advertises any meeting, theatrical performance, exhibition or event of any kind, for which an admission fee is charged for the purpose of private gain or profit; but the terms of the clause shall not apply where an admission fee is charged or a collection is taken up for the purpose of defraying the expenses incident to such meeting, theatrical performance, exhibition or event of any kind, when either of the same is held, given or takes place in connection with the dissemination of information which is not restricted under the ordinary rules of decency, good morals, public peace, safety and good order; provided that nothing contained in this clause shall be deemed to authorize the holding, giving or taking place of any meeting, theatrical performance, exhibition or event of any kind, without a license, where such license is or may be required by any law of this state, or under any ordinance of this city; or 
(4)  Which, while containing reading matter other than advertising matter, is predominantly and essentially an advertisement, and is distributed or circulated for advertising purposes, or for the private benefit and gain of any person so engaged as advertiser or distributor. 
    Garbage means putrescible animal and vegetable wastes resulting from the handling, preparation, cooking and consumption of food. 
    Litter means "garbage," "refuse" and "rubbish" as defined herein and all other waste material which, if thrown or deposited as herein prohibited, tends to create a danger to public health, safety and welfare. 
    Newspaper means any newspaper of general circulation as defined by general law, any newspaper duly entered with the Post Office Department of the United States, in accordance with federal statute or regulation, and any newspaper filed and recorded with any recording officer as provided by general law, and in addition thereto, shall mean and include any periodical or current magazine regularly published with not less than four issues per year, and sold to the public. 
    Noncommercial handbill means any printed or written matter, any sample or device, dodger, circular, leaflet, pamphlet, newspaper, magazine, paper, booklet or any other printed or otherwise reproduced original or copies of any matter of literature not included in the aforesaid definitions of a commercial handbill or newspaper. 
    Park means a park, reservation, playground, beach, recreation center or any other public area in the city, owned or used by the city and devoted to active or passive recreation. 
    Person means any person, firm, partnership, association, corporation, company or organization of any kind. 
    Private premises means any dwelling, house, building or other structure, designed or used whether wholly or in part for private residential purposes, whether inhabited or temporarily or continuously uninhabited or vacant, and shall include any yard, grounds, walk, driveway, porch, steps, vestibule or mailbox belonging or appurtenant to such dwelling, house, building or other structure. 
    Public place means any and all streets, sidewalks, boulevards, alleys or other public ways and any and all public parks, squares, spaces, grounds and buildings. 
    Refuse means all putrescible solid wastes (except body wastes), including garbage, rubbish, ashes, street cleanings, dead animals, abandoned automobiles and solid market and industrial wastes. 
    Rubbish means nonputrescible solid wastes consisting of both combustible and noncombustible wastes, such as paper, wrappings, cigarettes, cardboard, tin cans, yard clippings, leaves, wood, glass, bedding, crockery and similar materials. 
    Vehicle means every device in, upon or by which any person or property is or may be transported or drawn upon a highway, including devices used exclusively upon stationary rails or tracks. 
(Code 1996, § 46-82; Min. of 9-11-1962, § 2) 
Sec. 50-92. - Penalties. 
    Any person violating any of the provisions of this article shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction therefor, shall be fined in an amount not exceeding $100.00 or be imprisoned for a period not exceeding 30 days, or be both so fined and imprisoned. Each day such violation is committed or permitted to continue shall constitute a separate offense and be punishable as such hereunder. 
(Code 1996, § 46-103; Min. of 9-11-1962, § 23) 
State Law reference- Punishment for violation of ordinances, MCA 1972, § 21-13-1. 
Sec. 50-93. - Litter in public places. 
    No person shall throw or deposit litter in or upon any street, sidewalk or other public place within the city except in public receptacles, in authorized private receptacles for collection, or in official city dumps. 
(Code 1996, § 46-83; Min. of 9-11-1962, § 3) 
Sec. 50-94. - Placement of litter in receptacles so as to prevent scattering. 
    Persons placing litter in public receptacles or in authorized private receptacles shall do so in a manner as to prevent it from being carried or deposited by the elements upon any street, sidewalk or other public place or upon private property. 
(Code 1996, § 46-84; Min. of 9-11-1962, § 4) 
Sec. 50-95. - Sweeping litter into gutters prohibited. 
    No person shall sweep into or deposit in any gutter, street or other public place within the city the accumulation of litter from any building or lot or from any public or private sidewalk or driveway. Persons owning or occupying property shall keep the sidewalk in front of their premises free of litter. 
(Code 1996, § 46-85; Min. of 9-11-1962, § 5) 
Sec. 50-96. - Merchants duty to keep sidewalks free of litter. 
    No person owning or occupying a place of business shall sweep into or deposit in any gutter, street or other public place within the city the accumulation of litter from any building or lot or from any public or private sidewalk or driveway. Persons owning or occupying places of business within the city shall keep the sidewalk in front of their business premises free of litter. 
(Code 1996, § 46-86; Min. of 9-11-1962, § 6) 
Sec. 50-97. - Litter thrown by persons in vehicles. 
    No person, while a driver or passenger in a vehicle, shall throw or deposit litter upon any street or other public place within the city or upon private property. 
(Code 1996, § 46-87; Min. of 9-11-1962, § 7) 
Sec. 50-98. - Truck loads causing litter. 
    No person shall drive or move any vehicle or truck within the city, the wheels or tires of which carry onto or deposit in any street, alley or other public place, mud, dirt, sticky substances, liter or foreign matter of any kind. 
(Code 1996, § 46-88; Min. of 9-11-1962, § 8) 
State Law reference- Vehicles scattering load, MCA 1972, § 63-5-55. 
Sec. 50-99. - Litter in parks. 
    No person shall throw or deposit litter in any park within the city except in public receptacles and in such a manner that the litter will be prevented from being carried or deposited by the elements upon any part of the park or upon any street or other public place. Where public receptacles are not provided, all such litter shall be carried away from the park by the person responsible for its presence and properly disposed of elsewhere as provided herein. 
(Code 1996, § 46-89; Min. of 9-11-1962, § 9) 
Sec. 50-100. - Litter in lakes and fountains. 
(a)  Unlawful acts. 
(1)  No person, firm or corporation shall throw, place, or deposit litter in any fountain, pond, lake, stream, bay or other body of water in a park or elsewhere within the city. 
(2)  No person, firm or corporation, shall throw or place any refuse, paper, trash, glass, nails, tacks, wire, bottles, cans, yard trash, concrete, earthen fill, garbage, containers, litter or other debris or abandoned material of any nature in any ditch, stream, river or retention basin that regularly or periodically carries surface water run-off. 
(3)  No person, firm or corporation, shall deliberately or unintentionally place or dispose of grass clippings, brush, fill, trash, debris, obstructions or other unwanted or abandoned material of any nature onto the public street, roadway or sidewalks, or into the gutters or storm sewers or within or along the banks of any manmade or natural watercourse or in adjacent floodplain areas which may wash into the streams and storm sewers. 
(4)  No person, firm or corporation shall start, perform, carry out or complete any new construction or additions to existing construction without providing adequate measures to control or prevent building or construction debris or soil erosion from getting into any portion of the drainage system. 
(b)  Violation. Any such person or party who violates the provisions of this section is and shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, punishable as provided by law and hereinafter. Each occurrence or day of such occurrence continuing shall be a separate offense. 
(c)  Enforcement. The director of public works, any building or other inspector, or any law enforcement officer, may enforce these provisions as provided by law. 
(d)  Remedies cumulative. These provisions are cumulative and are in addition to any statutory or other lawful provisions and remedies. In the event the mayor and board of aldermen deem it necessary to bring any civil action to enforce the terms of these provisions, the violator shall be responsible for all court costs and legal fees and expenses incurred by the city therefor. 
(Code 1996, § 46-90; Min. of 9-11-1962, § 10; Ord. of 12-2-1997(2), § 1) 
Sec. 50-101. - Throwing or distributing handbills in public places. 
    No person shall throw or deposit any commercial or noncommercial handbill in or upon any sidewalk, street or other public place within the city. Nor shall any person hand out or distribute or sell any commercial handbill in any public place. Provided, however, that it shall not be unlawful on any sidewalk, street or other public place within the city for any person to hand out or distribute, without charge to the receiver thereof, any commercial or noncommercial handbill to any person willing to accept it. 
(Code 1996, § 46-91; Min. of 9-11-1962, § 11) 
Sec. 50-102. - Placing commercial and noncommercial handbills on vehicles. 
    No person shall throw or deposit any commercial or noncommercial handbill in or upon any vehicle except in a manner that will prevent the handbill from being blown about or scattered by the elements. 
(Code 1996, § 46-92; Min. of 9-11-1962, § 12) 
Sec. 50-103. - Depositing commercial and noncommercial handbills on uninhabited or vacant premises. 
    No person shall throw or deposit any commercial or noncommercial handbill in or upon any private premises which are temporarily or continuously uninhabited or vacant 
(Code 1996, § 46-93; Min. of 9-11-1962, § 13) 
Sec. 50-104. - Prohibiting distribution of handbills where property posted. 
    No person shall throw, deposit or distribute any commercial or noncommercial handbill upon any private premises, if requested by anyone thereon not to do so, or if there is placed on said premises in a conspicuous position near the entrance thereof, a sign bearing the words: "No Trespassing," "No Peddlers or Agents," "No Advertisement" or any similar notice, indicating in any manner that the occupants of said premises do not desire to be molested or have their right of privacy disturbed, or to have any such handbill left upon such premises. 
(Code 1996, § 46-94; Min. of 9-11-1962, § 14) 
Sec. 50-105. - Distributing commercial and noncommercial handbills at inhabited private premises. 
(a)  No person shall throw, deposit or distribute any commercial or noncommercial handbill in or upon private premises which are inhabited, except by handling or transmitting any such handbill directly to the owner, occupant, or other person then present in or upon such private premises. Provided, however, in case of inhabited private premises which are not posted, as provided in this article, such person, unless requested by anyone upon such premises not to do so, may place or deposit any such handbill in or upon such inhabited private premises, if such handbill is so placed or deposited as to secure or prevent such handbill from being blown or drifted about such premises or sidewalks, street or other public places, and except that mailboxes may not be so used when so prohibited by federal postal law or regulations. 
(b)  Exception for mail and newspapers. The provisions of this section shall not apply to the distributions of mail by the United States, nor to newspaper (as defined herein) except that newspapers shall be placed on private property in such a manner as to prevent their being carried or deposited by the elements upon any street, sidewalk or other public place or upon private property. 
(Code 1996, § 46-95; Min. of 9-11-1962, § 15) 
Sec. 50-106. - Dropping litter from aircraft. 
    No person in an aircraft shall throw out, drop or deposit within the city any litter, handbill or any other object. 
(Code 1996, § 46-96; Min. of 9-11-1962, § 16) 
Sec. 50-107. - Posting notices prohibited. 
    No person shall post or affix any notice, poster or other paper or device, calculated to attract the attention of the public, to any lamp post, public utility pole or shade tree, or upon any public structures or building, except as may be authorized or required by law. 
(Code 1996, § 46-97; Min. of 9-11-1962, § 17) 
Sec. 50-108. - Litter on occupied private property. 
    No person shall throw or deposit litter on any occupied private property within the city, whether owned by such person or not, except that the owner or person in control of private property may maintain authorized private receptacles for collection in such a manner that litter will be prevented from being carried or deposited by the elements upon any street, sidewalk or other public place or upon any private property. 
(Code 1996, § 46-98; Min. of 9-11-1962, § 18) 
Sec. 50-109. - Owner to maintain premises free of litter; removal of litter. 
(a)  The owner or person in control of any private property shall at all times maintain the premises free of litter. Provided, however, that this section shall not prohibit storage of litter in authorized private receptacles for collection. 
(b)  The collection, assembly, existence or gathering of unusable, discarded, abandoned, unused or potentially dangerous household or yard and garden appliances, furniture, fixtures or equipment in residentially zoned areas within the city is prohibited; and any person who owns real property upon which such debris is collected, assembled or deposited, or who asserts ownership of such debris in such residential areas, shall be unlawful. 
(c)  The public works department may remove from such property, by any and all means necessary to do so, all such household or yard and garden appliances, furniture, fixtures, equipment or supplies found and identified as being unsafe, unsightly or unclean by virtue of such items or debris having been discarded, abandoned, unused or unusable for the purpose for which they were intended. 
(Code 1996, § 46-99; Min. of 9-11-1962, § 19; Ord. of 4-9-2002, § 1) 
Sec. 50-110. - Litter on vacant lots. 
    No person shall throw or deposit litter on any open or vacant private property within the city, whether owned by such person or not. 
(Code 1996, § 46-100; Min. of 9-11-1962, § 20) 
Secs. 50-111-50-120. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - UNREASONABLE NOISE[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. of 06-07-2016(1) , adopted June 7, 2017, added provisions to the Code, but did not specify manner of inclusion. Therefore, at the discretion of the editor, said provisions have been included as §§ 50-121-50-126 herein. 

Sec. 50-121. - Unreasonable noise prohibited. 
    The creation of any unreasonably loud, disturbing noise in the city is hereby prohibited. Noises of such character, intensity and duration as are reasonably calculated to be detrimental to the life or health of any ordinary reasonable person are hereby prohibited. 
( Ord. of 06-07-2016(1), § 1 ) 
Sec. 50-122. - Enumeration of specific noises. 
    The following acts, among others, are declared to be loud, disturbing and unnecessary noises in violation of this chapter; provided, however, that such enumeration shall not be construed to be exclusive of other noises, to wit: 
(1)  The playing of any radio, phonograph or any musical instrument in such manner, or with such volume, particularly during the hours between 12:00 a.m. and 7:00 a.m., as to create a noise such as reasonably calculated to disturb a person of ordinary disposition under the same or similar circumstances residing in a dwelling or other type of residence in the vicinity. 
(2)  The use of any automobile, motorcycle, or vehicle so out of repair, so loaded or operated in such manner as to create loud noises such as spinning or squealing tires, grating, grinding, rattling or other noise. 
(3)  The erection (including excavation), demolition, alteration or repair of any building or other structure, or any other type of construction involving the use of heavy equipment, power equipment, or other tools creating excessive noise, other than between the hours of 6:30 a.m. and 7:00 p.m., Monday through Sunday, except when in the public interest, and then only with permission from the mayor and board of aldermen for a specific time. 
(4)  The creation of any excessive noise on any street adjacent to any school, institution of learning, or court while the same are in session, or adjacent to any hospital, which unreasonably interferes with the working of such institution, provided conspicuous signs are displayed in such streets indicating that the same is a school, hospital or court street. 
(5)  The use of any drum, loudspeaker or other instrument or device for the purpose of attracting attention to any performance, show or sale of merchandise. 
(6)  The failure of any person or persons to control and cease the unreasonable and/or habitual barking of any dog or dogs: 
a.  When said dog or dogs are in the possession of and/or being kept by said person or persons; and 
b.  When said barking creates a noise so as to disturb or disrupt the sleep or other normal activities of any other person. 
( Ord. of 06-07-2016(1), § 2 ) 
Sec. 50-123. - Certain uses of sound amplifying equipment by business establishments prohibited. 
(a)  The use of any loudspeaker or amplifier of sound attached to a building housing a business establishment in such manner that the sound coming from such loudspeaker or amplifier with such volume during the hours between 12:00 a.m. and 7:00 a.m., as to create a noise such as reasonably calculated to disturb a person of ordinary disposition under the same or similar circumstances residing in a dwelling or other type of residence in the vicinity shall be prohibited. 
(b)  The use or operation of any loudspeaker or amplifier of sound outside any building housing a business establishment in such a manner that the sound from such loudspeaker or amplifier with such volume during the hours between 12:00 a.m. and 7:00 a.m., as to create a noise such as reasonably calculated to disturb a person of ordinary disposition under the same or similar circumstances residing in a dwelling or other type of residence in the vicinity shall be prohibited. This prohibition includes any patios or porches or parts of a building that are not completely enclosed by walls and a roof. 
( Ord. of 06-07-2016(1), § 3 ) 
Sec. 50-124. - Sound level of vehicular audio systems. 
(a)  No person operating or occupying a motor vehicle on any street, highway, alley, parking lot, or driveway, either public or private property, shall operate or permit the operation of any sound amplification system, including, but not limited to, any radio, tape player, compact disc player, loud speaker, or any other electrical device used for the amplification of sound from within the motor vehicle so that the sound is plainly audible at a distance of 50 or more feet from the vehicle or, in the case of a motor vehicle on private property, beyond the property line. 
(b)  For the purpose of this subsection, "plainly audible" means any sound which clearly can be heard, by unimpaired auditory senses based on a direct line of sight of 50 or more feet, however, words or phrases need not be discernible and said sound shall include bass reverberation. 
(c)  Prohibitions contained in this section shall not be applicable to emergency or public safety vehicles, vehicles owned and operated by the municipal government, county government, state government, federal government or any utility company, for sound emitted unavoidably during job-related operation, or any motor vehicle used in an authorized public activity for which a permit has been granted by the appropriate agency of the city. 
(d)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Audio system means a device or combination of devices designed for the production, reproduction or amplification of sound including, but not limited to, any radio, stereo, tape deck, compact disc player or loudspeaker, which is operated in, installed in, or powered by a motor vehicle. 
    Motor vehicle, authorized emergency vehicle and highway mean as ascribed by the Mississippi Uniform Highway Traffic Regulations Law-Rules of the Road. 
( Ord. of 06-07-2016(1), § 4 ) 
Sec. 50-125. - Recognized exceptions. 
    The mayor and board of aldermen recognize that certain exceptions to the noise ordinance may be necessary when the event/concert/performance brings favorable notice to the city and encourages tourism. For such activities, the entity/person shall make application to the city for a waiver of the noise ordinance regulations for their specific event/concert/performance. Specifically exempted from the noise ordinance are the following: Octoberfest, Anotherfest, the Crosstie Festival, the Record Store Day Festival, Cleveland School District and Delta State University sponsored events/athletic events/music performances and all Grammy Museum events which the board finds and recognizes as unique events which promote tourism and bring favorable notice to the city. 
( Ord. of 06-07-2016(1), § 5 ) 
Sec. 50-126. - Penalty. 
    Any person violating any of the provisions of this section shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor, and, upon conviction thereof, shall be fined no more than: 
$100.00 1st offense $250.00 2nd offense $500.00 3rd offense $1000.00 4th offense  
( Ord. of 06-07-2016(1), § 6 ) 
State Law reference- Authority to regulate noise, MCA 1972, § 21-19-15. 
Chapter 54 - PARKS AND RECREATION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Municipal recreational facilities generally, MCA 1972, §§ 21-17-1, 21-19-31, 21-37-3. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 54-1. - Glass objects restricted. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to carry, possess, or use any glass object or container within any municipal public park, excluding, of course, eyeglasses, medicine containers, small face mirrors within purses or containers or vehicles with glass parts. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to break any glass object or place or cause to be placed any broken glass within any municipal park. 
(c)  Any park supervisor or police officer may require any person violating this section to immediately leave such park, and refusal to do so shall constitute a trespass or breach of the peace and shall be unlawful. 
(d)  If the presence of glass or broken glass within any park becomes dangerous to the use of the park or any portion thereof by vehicles or persons, then any park supervisor or police officer may declare such park to be closed within his sole discretion. Upon such closing, it shall be unlawful for any person to remain in the park, and such action may further be a trespass or breach of the peace. 
(Code 1996, § 50-1; Ord. of 11-2-1993) 
Sec. 54-2. - Closing hour. 
    It shall be unlawful to be in or upon any of the premises within the city designated as parks or public or private recreational facilities after the hour of 10:30 p.m.; provided that persons engaged in activities under the supervision of the recreation director of the city or invited upon premises and supervised by the owner thereof may conclude such activities as soon after 10:30 p.m. as possible in a quiet and orderly manner and provided further that the chief of police shall be notified of and approve such activity prior to its beginning if it will not be concluded at the specified hour. 
(Code 1996, § 50-2; Ord. of 8-4-1970, § 1) 
Secs. 54-3-54-22. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - PARK COMMISSION[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Authority to create, MCA 1972, § 21-37-33. 

Sec. 54-23. - Created. 
    To provide for the orderly management of recreational facilities for the wholesome and healthful recreation of the citizens of this city, there is hereby created a park commission. 
(Code 1996, § 50-26; Ord. of 6-4-1963, § 1) 
Sec. 54-24. - Composition; purpose. 
    The park commission shall consist of five commissioners, who shall be known as the "park commissioners" to manage and control all of the parks, playgrounds and recreation facilities maintained and established in the city. 
(Code 1996, § 50-27; Ord. of 6-4-1963, § 1) 
Sec. 54-25. - Budget. 
    The park commissioners and park commission shall confer with the mayor and board of aldermen for the purpose of planning a budget for its operation and that it shall perform such duties within the limit of funds therein provided and available. 
(Code 1996, § 50-29; Ord. of 6-4-1963, § 2) 
Secs. 54-26-54-53. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - PARK AND RECREATION ADVISORY BOARD 

Sec. 54-54. - Created. 
    An advisory board, to be known as the City of Cleveland Park and Recreation Advisory Board, is hereby created in and for the city. 
(Ord. of 2-2-2010(2), § 1) 
Sec. 54-55. - Purpose. 
    The City of Cleveland Park and Recreation Advisory Board is hereby established to advise the park commission director, the mayor and the board of aldermen with regard to the creation, maintenance and planning of supervised recreational facilities and programs in the city. 
(Ord. of 2-2-2010(2), § 2) 
Sec. 54-56. - Composition. 
    The board shall consist of seven members who serve staggered terms, to maintain continuity. The members shall be residents of the city. The seven members shall be appointed by the board of aldermen from a list of interested citizens. There shall be representation on the commission of citizens from each city ward. The park commission director shall serve as chairperson. Reappointments shall take place during the regular meeting of the mayor and board of aldermen in the month of October, or at the discretion of the mayor and board, with all members to serve until they have resigned or been replaced. Of the initial board, two positions shall be vacated as of the first Monday of October 2013, and three positions shall be vacated as of the first Monday of October 2014. At the end of each initial term, such positions shall be filled with appointments of three years. Members may be reappointed to any number of successive terms. 
(Ord. of 2-2-2010(2), § 3) 
Sec. 54-57. - Function of park commission director and park commission athletic director. 
    The park commission director, or equivalent city official, shall plan, coordinate and administer the activities involving the park system and recreational program in accordance with the goals, policy and procedures approved by the mayor and board of aldermen, and will be under the direction and supervision of the mayor and board of aldermen and the chief administrative officer. He is to be an ex officio member and chairperson for the advisory board. The park commission athletic director is to be an ex officio member and secretary for the advisory board. As secretary for the advisory board he shall keep minutes of all meetings, coordinate all correspondence for the board and serve as liaison to the mayor and board of aldermen. 
(Ord. of 2-2-2010(2), § 4) 
Sec. 54-58. - Meetings. 
    Meetings are to be held on a monthly basis, initially on the second Monday of each month. The time of the meeting is to be set by the advisory board. The location for meetings will be the office of the Cleveland Park Commission. 
(Ord. of 2-2-2010(2), § 5) 
Sec. 54-59. - Compensation. 
    All members of the advisory board shall serve without compensation. 
(Ord. of 2-2-2010(2), § 6) 
Sec. 54-60. - Powers and duties of advisory board. 
    The members of the advisory board shall devote such time and attentions to the duties of their office as the efficient performance thereof may demand and require. The general responsibilities are as follows, to wit: 
(1)  Advising with officials and leadership of recreation. 
(2)  Assisting in furthering the recreation program. 
(3)  Understanding all aspects of the program. 
(4)  Interpreting the program to the people of the city. 
(5)  Offering constructive suggestions and criticisms. 
(6)  Promoting needs and achieving results. 
(7)  Interpreting the wishes and desires of the citizens. 
(8)  Stimulating public involvement in decision making. 
(9)  Assisting with the proposed park commission financial budget. 
(10)  Consideration of current and future improvements. 
(11)  Establishment, monitoring and updating of a parks and recreation long range plan for current and future development. 
(12)  Establishment of an ongoing recruitment plan to ensure out of state/out of town tournaments choose Cleveland as a venue for their events. 
(Ord. of 2-2-2010(2), § 7) 
Secs. 54-61-54-78. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - WALKING TRAIL AND NATURE AREA 

Sec. 54-79. - Definitions. 
    Block party shall mean a gathering of neighbors or businesses for the purpose of fellowship, the beautification of an area, or the exposure of the residents to the arts or music that may or may not require the use or blocking of any portion of the regulated area. The definition of block parties includes barbeques, picnic, music, games, dances or exhibits of arts, crafts or performances. 
    Other special events shall mean street fair, art and craft show, carnival, block party or other neighborhood or community activity, picnic, dance, rally, promotional or fund raising activities, community celebrations and observances, and other special events which occur within said regulated area so as to impede, obstruct, impair, delay or interfere with the recreational or preservation uses by any other person for which the area is designated or requires any special municipal efforts to protect and preserve the property uses otherwise intended herein. 
    Regulated area shall mean the area described and embraced as described in 54-81 and may be referred to as the "trailway," and the regulations herein are applicable and in effect within such area. 
(Ord. of 6-2-2014, § 12; Ord. of 02-05-2019(3), § 12 ) 
Sec. 54-80. - Violation and penalty. 
(a)  Any violation of the provisions of this ordinance shall be unlawful and punishable as for a misdemeanor as provided by law. 
(1)  First offense: Fines of no less than $25.00 and no more than $100.00. 
(2)  Second offense: Fines of no less than $100.00 and no more than $250.00. 
(3)  Third offense: Fines of no less than $250.00 and no more than $500.00. 
(4)  Fourth and each subsequent offense: Fines of no less than $500.00 and no more than $1,000.00. 
(b)  In order to prevent breach of the intended or peaceful use of the regulated premises and damage to any portion thereof, any violator may be immediately ordered to leave the premises and failure to obey such order shall be a violation punishable as herein provided and subject to immediate arrest or citation as provided by law and by the ordinances of this city. 
(c)  This article is cumulative, and the city may undertake and initiate any other lawful remedy for the enforcement of this article and these regulations. 
(Ord. of 6-2-2014, § 14; Ord. of 02-05-2019(3), § 14 ) 
Sec. 54-81. - Boundary of area. 
    The nature and walking trail herein, together hereinafter "the trailway," are hereby designated a municipal park and encompass that area in The City of Cleveland, Mississippi, described as follows: 
(1)  Area One. That property acquired by The City of Cleveland, Mississippi in the Southwest Quarter (SW 1/4) of Section 16, Township 22 North, Rage 5 West lying North of the North line of Sunflower Road, which is also designated as Mississippi State Highway 8, more particularly described in that deed from Columbus and Greenville Railway Company now of record beginning on page 624 of Land Deed Record M-230 of the records in the office of the Chancery Clerk of Bolivar County, Mississippi, in said city. 
(2)  Area Two. That property bounded on the North by the South line of said Sunflower Road and on the South by the North line of College and Lee Streets; and, Bounded on the West by the East line of Cotton Row, formerly known as Central Avenue, between said Sunflower Road and the center line of South Court Street, by the West line of Bayou Avenue, from said center line of South Court Street, between said center line of South Court Street and the South line of the Commerce building property, and by the West line of Jones Bayou, between said South line of the Commerce Building property and the North line of said College and Lee Streets; and, Bounded on the East by the West line of Sharpe Avenue; and this Area Two also includes property acquired from said Railway and other property acquired by said city. 
(3)  Area Three. That property in Sections 21 and 28, Township 22 North, Range 5 West lying South of the South line of College Street and Lee Street acquired by The City of Cleveland, Mississippi, and more particularly described, by that deed from Columbus and Greenville Railway Company now of record beginning on page 638 of Land Deed Record M-230 of the records in the office of the Chancery Clerk of Bolivar County, Mississippi, in said city. 
(Ord. of 6-2-2014, § 1; Ord. of 02-05-2019(3), § 1 )
